story: The EU chief Brexit negotiator made the admission of his concerns at a meeting of EU lawmakers a person familiar with the situation told Reuters.Michel Barnier reiterated that for a deal to be struck between the EU and Britain, Prime Minister Theresa May must make compromises.On Wednesday, he tweeted that he was &ldquoworking for an orderly Brexit and a new partnership that respects the UK's sovereignty, as well as the founding principles of the EU, such as the integrity of the single market.One diplomat involved in Brexit talks said confidence that a deal was in the offing is starting to recede.                Labour in CHAOS: 'Nobody is ruling out remaining in EU' warns Keir                 David Davis claims Theresa May is DISINGENUOUS amid fresh calls to ...He said: &ldquoI am less optimistic now. I&rsquom not so sure any more.This comes after a senior official working for the European commission President Jean-Claude Junker beefed EU ambassadors from the remaining 27 member states on how to manage an abrupt British departure.According to Reuters, diplomats and officials said the latest round of discussions were a sign of determination to cope with a &ldquohard Brexit if Britain refuses to bow to the EU&rsquos terms.But views differ on whether this signalled a greater degree of urgency or fears of a no-deal Brexit.One EU diplomat said: There's a wish not to rock the boat with too much 'no deal' posturing.&ldquoIt's simply a calendar issue - if we want to be sure we're prepared, we need to move forward.SCROLL DOWN FOR LIVE UPDATESBrexit: Michel Barnier has doubts whether a deal can be struck by his mid-November deadline (Image: EPA)8.31pm update: Tory Brexiteer calls for May to resign&nbspNadine Dorries has called on Theresa May to resign, accusing the Prime Minister of letting people down because she has handcuffed herself to this Chequers deal.&nbspThe Brexiteer and MP for mid-Bedfordshire, appearing on ITV's Peston programme, was asked if she believed Mrs May should go, to which she replied tes.&nbspMs Dorries added:&nbspI think that if we don't, I say it in sorrow because I was delighted when Theresa May was Prime Minister and I have been saying for many, many months to people, 'trust her, she will deliver'.Sadly she has let me down and she's let other people down because she isn't delivering, she isn't delivering because she has handcuffed herself to this Chequers deal.The MP also repeated comments from former minister and fellow ERG member Mark Francois that Tory Eurosceptics would refuse to back Mrs May's Chequers plan.&nbspMs dorries added: The Prime Minister needs to climb down and she needs to support a Canada plus free trade agreement.7.02pm update: EU ambassadors meet for 'closed session' to discuss no-deal Brexit impacts - reportEU ambassadors are set to hold a rare 'closed session' on Wednesday night to discuss the prospect of UK Parliament rejecting the final orce settlement.&nbspTopics for discussion are expected to include possible sub-deals to keep aircraft flying, medicine supllies and ports moving.Talks will reportedly focus on using the legal basis of Article 50 exit talks to absorb the effects of a no-deal if and when it becomes apparent that negotiations are grinding to a halt and that time will run out befre Britain leaves the bloc on March 29, 2019.A restricted agenda, seen by The Times, states:&nbspPreparedness work has to intensify in the months ahead at national as well as EU level as uncertainty remains about the outcome of the negotiations and the ratification of a possible deal.6.12pm update: Barnier backtracks on mid-November deadline for final Brexit deal&nbspMichel Barnier reportedly has doubts over whether his mid-November target of agreeing an outline deal and final package with Britain will be met, adding further doubts over whether a Brexit agreement will be struck.&nbspThe EU's chief Brexit negotiator made the admission to EU lawmakers on Tuesday, a person familiar with the meeting told Reuters.&nbspEU leaders, who rejected Theresa May's Chequers plan at a summit in Salzburg last week, have insisted she must make compromises.&nbspOne diplomat involved in Brexit talks said his confidence that a deal was in the offing had started to recede.I am less optimistic now. I&rsquom not so sure any more.This comes after a senior official working for European Commission President Jean-Claude Junker briefed ambassadors from the remaining 27 member states on plans to deal with Britain tumbling out of the bloc without a deal.&nbsp&nbsp                May positive of Chequers Brexit deal as she says EU unity CRUMBLING                RELIEF! Brexit delays AVERTED as Irish government FACES DOWN vote5.47pm update: Irish Finance Minister warns of significant shock to economy with no-deal BrexitIreland's Finance Minister has warned a no-deal Brexit would be a significant shock to the booming economy in the contry.&nbspPaschal Donohoe said if Britain tumbled out of the bloc without an agreement with Brussels, the Republic's productivity would grow by just 2-3 percent instead of 3-4 percent.&nbspHe said Ireland would also face exceptional swings in the value of sterling, which would have knock-on effects for trade.&nbspMr Donohoe added a disorderly Brexit would hit Ireland's financial sector in areas such as money flow and insurance contracts.&nbspThe UK is Ireland's main trading partner - around a third of the Republic's exports head across the Irish Sea.The Finance Minister, giving evidence to the Irish Parliament's select committee on budgetary oversight, warned:&nbspIt would be a very significant shock for our economy.It is likely that our economy would still grow but at a significantly lower rate.He predicted major structural change in Ireland's economic relationship with the UK after the orce, adding: There will be many new obligations on Irish, European and British companies.Mr Donohoe also repeated that more customs and agriculture officials will be required.Brexit: Philip Hammond has moved the autumn budge forward to avoid a clash with a key Brussels summi (Image: )4.48pm update: Autumn budget moved forward to October 29 to aoid clash with key Brexit summitPhilip Hammond has moved forward his autumn budget to October 29 to avoid a clash with Brexit negotiations, according to the Financial Times.&nbspThe budget would come just a week after a crucial Brexit summit in Brussels on October 18 where a final Brexit deal could be thrashed out. It would also be three weeks earlier than last year&nbspThe Chancellor is expected to use the setpiece economic statement to reassure markets as the UK prepares to exit the EU.&nbspMr Hammond said on Twitter:&nbspI'll set out how our balanced approach is getting debt falling while supporting our vital public services, and how we are building a stronger, more prosperous economy.4.11pm update: Business leaders tell May of daunting BrexitBusiness leaders have told Theresa May of their fears over Brexit, asking for more reassurances from the Prime Minister.&nbspMrs May had taken to the stage at a gathering of corporate bosses in New York to sell post-Brexit Britain as the best low-tax, high-skilled place to invest in.&nbspBut during a question and answer session following her speech, Steve Schwarzman, CEO at investment firm Blackstone, warned the UK's exit from the EU was daunting.&nbspHe said: In terms of downside management, we actually just bought a thing in the UK last week so I guess we are believers.But on the other side, things could really go off with a bad Brexit and also a change of government.The thing that we really worry about is how bad can things get?We believe in the good thing. But in terms of just thinking about it from a risk management perspective it's a little daunting for those of us on the outside.IBM CEO Ginni Rometty quizzed the Prime Minister over the risks posed to business from a bad Brexit.&nbspShe said: All of us are in the business of enterprise risk management and so as we talk about Brexit.What would you do in our shoes to be planning right now? What would you do now to balance that risk?Brexit: Jeremy Corbyn warned that crashing out of the EU would be a 'national disaster' (Image: )3.46pm update: Pound falls slightly but analysts remain optimisticThe pound fell on Wednesday as investors remained cautious about negotiations between Brtain and the EU on a Brexit deal.Sterling slipped marginally by 0.1 percent to $1.3171 but will above the $1.3041 low it plummeted to last Friday.&nbspThe currency gained 0.2 percent to trade at 89.14 pence per eurohaving initally fallen against the single currency, which weakened in New York trading.&nbspMichael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets, said:&nbspThe pound has continued its recent recovery after the sell-off at the end of last week.&ldquoConcerns that we might see another election appear to have disappeared for the time being, after Prime Minister May pushed back hard on the idea when questioned about it on her way to the UN in New York.3.25pm update: Flights between Ireland and UK could be grounded, warns aviation headFlights between Ireland and the UK could be grounded in the event of a no-deal Brexit, the boss of Ireland's aviation authority has warned.&nbspIn his evidence to the country's transport, tourism and sport committee on Wednesday,&nbspMichael McGrail, the chair of the Irish Aviation Authority (IAA), spoke of the challenges the industry faces, warning the implications would start from midnight on March 29 - the date the UK leaves the EU.&nbspHe said:&nbspGiven the apparent impasse between the UK and the EU, a satisfactory withdrawal agreement, transition period and then future relationship is in doubt, he said.Apart from the disruption for aviation and the travelling public, a hard Brexit would have a significant negative impact on our wider economy.The Department of Transport is carrying out scenario planning to ensure minimal negative consequences and the IAA is working in close collaboration with the department and other agencies in this regard.Pressed on the practical implications for the public and whether a no-deal Brexit would result in flights coming to an abrupt end, Mr McGrail added: If there is a hard Brexit, then the UK becomes a third country and therefore both the air traffic management and air safety regulations that currently govern, not only the UK but the rest of Europe, would fall away.There obviously would be immediate practical issues I suppose from midnight on March 29.Having said that we know the Department is working on practical solutions to that and they have a number of scenarios they are looking at and we are working closely with them to see how those scenarios would actually work.The IAA nor the Irish Government can control this. It's very much the EU.Theresa May addressed business leaders in New York (Image: )2.47pm update: Corbyn 'unfit to govern', says Tory Chairman&nbspConservative Chairman Brandon Lewis has blasted the prospect of Jeremy Corbyn becoming Prime Minister, with working families feeling the biggest impact.&nbspHe said: Jeremy Corbyn has shown at every turn he is unfit to govern.All he offers are failed ideas that didn't work in the past and would leave working families paying the price with higher taxes, more debt and more waste - just like last time.2.33pm update: Corbyn has 'thrown down the gauntlet to the Tories'&nbspEloise Todd, leader of the Best for Britain capaign for a second referendum, has heaped praise on Jeremy Corbyn's speech and called for a People's Vote with the option to stay.&nbspShe said:&nbspJeremy Corbyn has thrown down the gauntlet to the Tories by challenging them to meet Keir Starmer's six tests, but it's clear that this government can't do that. The extreme Brexiteers in the Tory party certainly can't.No form of Brexit can deliver the six tests or what Labour wants - the current deadlock in Parliament and in negotiations with the EU show that. Only our current deal with the EU can meet those tests.That's why the only way out of this mess is to call a People's Vote with the option to stay. Then the public can compare our current bespoke deal with whatever this government cobbles together.2.26pm update: Labour will offer Scotland 'economic chaos and incompetence' - SNP&nbspThe SNP's Westminster leader Ian Blackford has blasted Labour's plans for Scotland, claiming they aren't fit for opposition, let alone Government.&nbspHe said: Labour have proven they have nothing to offer Scotland but economic chaos and incompetence - failing to provide any meaningful alternative to the Tories.After a bitterly ided conference, dominated by rows over Brexit, racism, and sectarianism, Labour have shown they aren't even fit for opposition let alone government.Jeremy Corbyn delivers his Brexit vision to the Labour Party conference (Image: )2.10pm update: 'We will vote it down!' Labour MP warns over May's plan for BrexitShadow Equalities Minister Dawn Butler&nbsp warned if Theresa May is unable to strike a good Brexit deal, Labout will vote it down.&nbspShe said:&nbspWhat we're trying to do is make clear what's at stake here - we've already said we need to protect our standards and services, workers' rights and jobs.The six steps still stand and it is up to the Prime Minister to negotiate a good deal or we will vote it down.2.01pm update: 'Great lift in the conference' - Shadow Housing Secretary John Healy&nbspJohn Healy has hailed the great lift in Labour's conference, adding the party is ready to negotiate Brexit and lead Britain.&nbspSpeaking to the Press Association, the Shadow Housing Secretary said: There's a great lift in the conference - it's part of all this week Labour setting out a plan about what we would do in government to rebuild the country.Mr Corbyn also set out today a big challenge to Theresa May on Brexit.We've said consistently for over a year the tests a good deal must meet. If she recognises that, does a deal and meets those tests then we'll back her in Parliament.If she can't do a deal that meets those tests we'll oppose it, if she can't do a deal that gets through Parliament then she must have an election - we have to change the team, not just the plan, and we're ready to negotiate Brexit and lead Britain.Asked which option is most likely, Mr Healey said the honest answer is no-one knows before adding Labour is clear over the points which it will challenge.Brexit: Michel Barnier will hold talks after the Labour Party conference tomorrow (Image: )Paul Withers taking over live reporting from Simon Osborne.2.03pm update: May addresses business leaders in New YorkTheresa May&nbsphas told executives at a business forum organised by the former New York mayor Michael Bloomberg &ldquoa post-Brexit Britain will be an unequivocally pro-business Britain.The Prime Minister said businesses investing in Britain will receive the lowest rate of corporation tax in the G20.She said: &ldquoYou will access service industries and a financial centre in London that are the envy of the world, the best universities, strong institutions, a sound approach to public finance and a consistent and dependable approach to high standards but intelligent regulation.Mrs May said her Chequers proposals had &ldquomuch common ground with the EU, despite its rejection at an informal summit of the union&rsquos leaders last week in Salzburg.She said: &ldquoThere is no other plan that protects jobs and livelihoods and also meets our commitments in Northern Ireland, while respecting how people voted in the largest democratic exercise in our history.&ldquoWith the conclusion of the negotiations over the coming weeks, the certainty of an implementation period in which to adapt to the new arrangements, and the guarantee of frictionless trade with the EU in the future, business can look forward to the post-Brexit world with confidence.Brexit: Brandon Lewis hit out at Jeremy Corbyn, claiming he is 'unfit to govern' (Image: )1.36pm update: Tories respond to Jeremy Corbyn&rsquos Brexit commentsThe Conservatives responded to&nbspJeremy Corbyn&rsquos conference speech on social media.They Tweeted: &ldquoJust now @jeremycorbyn claimed Labour would respect the EU referendum result...&ldquoBut yesterday he backed @Keir_Starmer who said &lsquonobody is ruling out remain&rsquo&ldquoWhat's clear is that they would take us all back to square one on Brexit.1.30pm update: Corbyn - &ldquoBrexit is about the future of our country and our vital interestsJeremy Corbyn has told the Labour conference his party respects the decision of the British people in the EU referendum but warned crashing out of the EU would be a &ldquonational disaster.He told delegates in Liverpool: &ldquoOur priority is clear &ndash we aim to get the best Brexit deal for jobs and living standards to underpin our plans to upgrade the economy and invest in every community and region.&ldquoThat can bring people together and meet the concerns of both those who voted leave and those who voted remain.&ldquoWe will vote against any reduction in rights, standards or protections and oppose a deregulatory race-to-the-bottom.&ldquoLabour will vote against the Chequers plan or whatever is left of it and oppose leaving the EU with no deal.&ldquoAnd it is inconceivable that we should crash out of Europe with no deal &ndash that would be a national disaster.                Labour MP refuses to admit second Brexit vote is UNDEMOCRATIC                Jeremy Corbyn to meet Barnier as Labour threatens to REVERSE Brexit12.14pm update: Barnier and Corbyn to hold talksEuropean Union chief Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier has announced plans to meet Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn.Mr Barnier&rsquos office said the pair will hold talks tomorrow after the Labour Party conference in Liverpool.The meeting comes after Mr Corbyn and his shadow frontbench team distanced themselves from talk of a second EU referendum.11.45am update: Raab meets Gibraltar&rsquos Fabian PicardoBrexit Secretary Dominic Raab had held talks with Gibraltar&rsquos Chief Minister Fabian Picardo.Mr Raab said: &ldquoI was delighted to welcome Mr Picardo for a discussion about the shared opportunities that lie ahead as the UK and Gibraltar leave the EU together.&ldquoWe had a productive conversation about the importance of UK-Gibraltar ties and the vital work going on to deepen and strengthen these into the future.&ldquoThe UK is fully involving Gibraltar as we negotiate our departure from the EU, and this meeting was just one of the many ways in which we are ensuring that their priorities are taken into account.&ldquoI look forward to working together to secure a prosperous future for the UK and Gibraltar outside the EU.Dominic Raab welcomes Fabian Picardo (Image: DEXEU)10.22am update: Labour figures play down chances of second referendumSenior shadow cabinet members have distanced Labour from a second Brexit referendum the day after party delegates voted to keep the option on the table.Rebecca Long-Bailey, the shadow business secretary, said the party would not include a new referendum in its manifesto if a general election was called before March.Mrs Long-Bailey told BBC Radio 5 Live that Sir Keir's motion, hammered out after a late-night meeting, respected the 2016 referendum result.Asked if a new vote would be among a list of manifesto pledges if Theresa May sent the country to the polls before Brexit day in March, she said no.She added that a second referendum was hypothetical, adding: What we have said is that, in a very extreme set of circumstances, nothing should be ruled out, and that includes a People's Vote.She said it was not impossible Labour would vote to support a deal made by the Prime Minister, but added we are a long way away from anything the party could back being produced.9.03am update: Labour &ldquoaccepts and respects Brexit decisionShadow justice secretary Richard Burgon said Labour's policy remained that we accept and respect the outcome of the referendum.Asked on LBC radio about Sir Keir Starmer leaving open the door to a second poll, he said: Who knows where history is going to go?He added: The Labour Party isn't calling for a second referendum.Labour has our own vision of Brexit, respecting, accepting the outcome of the referendum.8.30am update: Labour MP warns of &ldquoelectoral peril of ignoring referendum resultLabour Brexiteer Graham Stringer warned there could be real electoral peril if the EU referendum result was not implemented.The MP for Blackley and Broughton told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: I think the actual resolution backed yesterday was a classic Labour Party conference fudge.I think there is real electoral peril if we start going back on that commitment, not just not from many Labour Leave voters and people who voted Labour in the past and voted Leave, but there's also a respect for democracy amongst people who voted Remain who just respect the decision and want us to get on to it because all the major party leaders gave a commitment that the referendum would be implemented.Asked if he would back the Prime Minister if she secured a deal, he said: It depends entirely what the deal is.&ldquoIf she continues with the nonsense of Chequers, no, I would vote against that.&ldquoIf it meets the Labour Party's manifesto commitments and the expectations of the referendum, I'm a democrat, I would respect that referendum decision.7.30am update: French minister says EU future more important than BrexitFrench Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire said the EU has more pressing priorities than Britain's future relationship with Brussels.EU leaders have rejected Theresa May's proposals for post-Brexit trade, standing firm on their position that the plan would undermine the single market.Mr Le Maire said: The British made their choice, that's fine.&ldquoExcuse me to say so brutally, but there are more important things for us than the future of the United Kingdom. It's the future of the European Union.Any decision that gives European citizens the impression that you can leave the European Union and keep all the advantages would be suicidal.7am update: Thinktank urges May to extend Brexit timelineScotland&rsquos Fraser of Allander Institute has warned extending the Brexit timeline could be essential for the UK&rsquos future prosperity.It said jobs and livelihoods could be a risk in the event of a no-deal scenario and urged the Government to push back the Article 50 deadline for leaving the bloc.

story: The late People&rsquos Princess was the first royal bride who worked before her wedding (Image: )The late People&rsquos Princess was the first royal bride who worked in the run-up to her 1981 nuptials to Prince Charles.After attending finishing school in Switzerland, Princess Diana was a nursery school teacher.She worked at the Young England School in Pimlico, London, and is believed to have been the very first royal to have worked after marrying into the family.Fans of the royals will no doubt already know that Meghan Markle, 37, had her own career before she married Prince Harry and became the Duchess of Sussex on May 19.                Princess Eugenie news: Jack Brooksbank is &lsquonot the most intelligent'                Royal Wedding MAP: Procession route and best places to see Eugenie ...She was an actress in US TV programme Suits, having played popular character Rachel Zane for seven years before giving her acting dreams up to marry the son of Princess Diana.Kate, Duchess of Cambridge, also worked in the run-up to her wedding to Prince William in 2011 having devoted her time to fashion giant Jigsaw.Bride-to-be Eugenie is also a working royal and works for an art dealer.Last year, the 28-year-old granddaughter of the Queen was promoted to director at Hauser &amp Wirth, a contemporary art gallery in London where she has spent the past three years working.                Royal wedding news: Princess Eugenie to have BUDGET version of Megh...Princess Eugenie will continue to work after her wedding (Image: )Princess Eugenie will continue to work after her wedding and in June, five months after the announcement of her engagement to Mr Brooksbank, 32, it was announced Eugenie scooped a second job as ambassador for global marine charity Project Zero.She said in an Instagram post at the time: &ldquoI'm so excited to have recently become an Ambassador of Project 0 whose aim is to restore and protect the ocean.In just two weeks Eugenie and Mr Brooksbank will flock to Windsor to tie the knot in a lavish ceremony at St George&rsquos Chapel on October 12.Her cousin Prince Harry wed Meghan there in spring and like bride-to-be Eugenie also will, they undertook a carriage procession through Windsor where they greeted the 100,000 well-wishers after becoming husband and wife.

title: Hockney tribute glass Queen love nature
story: Artist David Hockney poses in front of The Queen's Window (Image: Victoria Jones - WPA PoolGetty Images)She and other senior royals will see The Queen&rsquos Window for the first time at a remembrance service in November marking the centenary of the end of the First World War.&nbspThe 26ft abstract window, depicting a hawthorn blossom in the Yorkshire countryside, was commissioned by the Dean of Westminster, the Very Rev Dr John Hall.&nbspIt replaces a plain glass window dating from the Second World War. It is Hockney&rsquos first venture in stained glass and the undisclosed costs were met by private donations.&nbspThe 81-year-old said the iPad was natural to use as it is &ldquoback-lit like a window.&nbspBut he admitted it was a challenge, adding: &ldquoI&rsquove learned something about glass. Asked whether he had heard from the Queen, he said: &ldquoNot yet, but I hope she&rsquoll like it. I&rsquom sure she will.&nbsp                Inside the Queen&rsquos official residence in Canada: How beloved hall f...                Queen and Philip pose with dead tiger years before Prince William Hockney, who once turned down the chance to paint the Queen&rsquos portrait because he was &ldquovery busy painting England actually, her country, chose a hawthorn as a celebration of spring and summer and said he was inspired by artists Matisse, Chagall, &ldquoand a few other people for the new work.&nbspAn Abbey spokesman said: &ldquoThe subject reflects the Queen as a countrywoman and her widespread delight in, and yearning for, the countryside.Dr Hall said: &ldquoI&rsquom excited by it. I think there&rsquos absolutely no harm at all in having something which is particular and vibrant and different.&ldquoIt&rsquos going to be here until the end. I mean, who knows what&rsquos going to happen in the future? The Abbey&rsquos only been here just over 1,000 years. It&rsquoll be here thousands more.&nbspBarley Studio, based in York, created the window.Estelle Lovatt, Fellow of the Royal Society of Arts and art critic (Image: NC)YES, says Estelle Lovatt, Fellow of the Royal Society of Arts and art criticI AM definitely in favour of this piece.&nbspI love the colours.&nbspHockney, probably the most influential artist of our time, has not deviated from the usual way that he uses his iPad to draw or paint so he is staying true to his preferred medium.&nbspI love the fact that he is using modern technology to design it, but traditional stained glass makers&rsquo style to actually create it.&nbspYou can recognise it as a Hockney anywhere.&nbsp                &lsquoWe all panic&rsquo Prince Harry says how he feels when bumping into Queen                I hope the Queen likes it! Artist unveils stained glass window tributeA view of The Queen's Window, a new stained glass window at Westminster Abbey (Image: Victoria Jones - WPA PoolGetty Images)This is a wonderful use of bright colours and when the sun shines through them it will be like looking at it on the iPad.&nbspArtists throughout history loved creating imagery for and through the church, but this doesn&rsquot have any religious symbolism that you would normally expect to find.&nbspIt&rsquos all to do with nature.&nbspNot only does the Queen love the landscape, so does Hockney, coming from Yorkshire.&nbspHe chose spring and summer, a time when we are celebrating life, so he is using that time not only to celebrate life, but also the Queen and her reign.&nbspI&rsquom looking forward to standing below the stained glass window to feel the warmth of the colours.&nbspI&rsquom sure it will be a magical moment.Ruth Millington, Art and culture critic (Image: NC)NO, says Ruth Millington,&nbspArt and culture criticDAVID Hockney joins numerous other famous artists, including Marc Chagall and Henri Matisse, who have created modern artworks in this traditional medium.&nbspHowever, I was disappointed by the Westminster Abbey design.&nbspToday, what Hockney does best is paint large panoramas of the English countryside.&nbspFields and hedgerows stretch across space, imagined in dazzling colour.&nbspHere, there is no space.&nbspThe hawthorn blossom illustration is crammed into a pair of narrow, pointed panels.&nbspThe pathway leading up to the trees is ided disruptively in two by the church architecture.&nbspThe image also lacks Hockney&rsquos usual craftsmanship and the scene is too simplistic: abstracted shapes appear awkward and lazily drawn.&nbspLacking perspective and depth, the window doesn&rsquot draw you in.&nbspI&rsquom guessing he knocked this design up on his iPad in an hour or so.&nbspLess of a landscape, and more of a brightly-coloured decoration, David Hockney&rsquos design lacks feeling, majesty or power.&nbspIt also fails to tell a story, which is part of the stained glass window&rsquos sacred role.

title: Brexit news Labour Conference 2018 Jeremy Corbyn second referendum keir starmer
story: Labour Party member David Mallen dismantled calls for a second Brexit referendum arguing backing a new vote could cost the party the support of Northern Leave voters.Speaking at the Labour Party Conference in Liverpool he launched a scathing attack on the European Union,&nbspmaking claims of&nbspunfair treatment of workers.He said: I am against having a 'people&rsquos vote' on the basis that in my constituency we voted overwhelmingly to leave and my worry is, if we go against the people&rsquos will, we&rsquoll lose those voters.I implore you all, come to Blythe Valley, go to Cowpen ward, tell them why you want us to remain and go to Kitty Brewster, where for too long they&rsquove felt marginalised like they have not had their voices heard. I personally would have voted Remain at the time but now I&rsquom against it because I believe the European Union to be a capitalist club that is for the few, not the many.                Jeremy Corbyn to meet Barnier as Labour threatens to REVERSE BrexitMr Mallen insisted that membership of the European single market and customs union had had negative effects on workers' rights, hinting at leaving the bloc as a solution to help struggling workers.He also called for a general election to put an end to Theresa May's Government to install Jeremy Corbyn to Number 10 and to see Labour take over the last phase of the Brexit negotiations.&nbspMr Mallen continued: It uses free trade to take advantage of those who are in Eastern Europe, Romanians who come over for a better life and their wages are undercut because the bosses think, because of the European Union, they can pay them less. This is a complete and utter farce. We must work to actually improve our nation for all the people in this country.Since Thatcher brought in free trade with Europe, that is when things went downhill. So I implore you, we need a general election, not a people&rsquos vote.Brexit news: Mr Mallen launched a scathing attack on the EU 'capitalist club' (Image: &bullPA)He added: We need the Tories out so we can get a man like Jeremy Corbyn to negotiate because I&rsquove seen videos of Michel Barnier and Corbyn being friendlier than he is with David Davis or Dominic Raab or whatever his name is.Corbyn will negotiate far better than what these Tories can do.In spite of Mr Mallen's passionate speech against a second referendum, Labour members passed a motion to keep the option of a new vote on the table&nbspOnly a small minority were against the motion, which would pave the way for MPs to reject any exit deal that fails to meet Labour&rsquos six &lsquotests&rsquo.Shadow Brexit Secretary Sir Keir Starmer set out the criteria last year and the tests have since become official party policy.Both Sir Keir and shadow foreign secretary Emily Thornberry told the conference that they would personally&nbspvote&nbspRemain in any re-run referendum.                Jeremy Corbyn SPEECH: Read the Labour leader's speech in FULL                 Emily Thornberry CONFIDENT Labour would win in election forecastBrexit news: Jeremy Corbyn insisted Labour will respect the referendum results (Image: BBC)But Mr Corbyn himself repeatedly declined to say which way he would vote, telling Five News: It depends what the question is in the referendum... We will decide as a party when the referendum comes what our position will be.Addressing the conference on Wednesday, Mr Corbyn insisted Labour would not overturn Brexit but questioned the conduct of the May Government during the negotiations with Brussels.Mr Corbyn said: &ldquoLabour respects the decision of the British people in the referendum but no one can respect the conduct of the government since that vote took place.As it stands, Labour will vote against the Chequers plan or whatever is left of it and oppose leaving the EU with no deal. And it is inconceivable that we should crash out of Europe with no deal &ndash that would be a national disaster.That is why if Parliament votes down a Tory deal or the government fails to reach any deal at all we would press for a general election.Failing that, all options are on the table. Brexit is about the future of our country and our vital interests.BREXIT NEWS: LATEST LIVE UPDATES

story: Labour MP Graham Stringer ripped into the Government's &ldquocrazy negotiating stance and demanded Prime Minister Theresa May &ldquorethink her Chequers Brexit proposal, which was bluntly rejected by the European Union at an informal summit in Salzburg last week.Speaking exclusively to Express, Mr Stringer said: &ldquoI think the Government has been appalling in the way they have conducted the negotiations.&ldquoThe Chequers deal &ndash the EU made it clear from the very beginning and they wouldn&rsquot accept any close. The House of Commons also knows there is not a majority for the Chequers deal because it effectively ties us to the rules of the European Union forever. So, no majority in the House of Commons.&ldquoNo deal with the EU is a crazy negotiating stance position. Hopefully, now that the EU and their arrogant way have told Theresa May that they are not having it, the Government will rethink and come up with something that might get through the Commons and get through the European Union.The EU rejected the Prime Minister&rsquos Chequers proposal last week in a series of attacks on both the Prime Minister and Brexiteers.On Thursday French President Emmanuel Macron branded Brexiteers as &ldquoliars while Donald Tusk President of the European Council Donald Tusk mocked the Prime Minister's attempts to push forward with the Brexit negotiations.Mr Tusk published a scathing social media picture taking aim at perceived cherry picking aspects of her Chequers plan.The European Council president shared a photo of himself presenting Mrs May with a cake stand in a gesture seemingly mocking at the Brexit prover you can have your cake and eat it.Graham Stringer hit out at EU over Brexit (Image: EXPRESS)He also told the Prime Minister she will have to rethink her Chequers blueprint for Brexit, saying the plan will not work in its present form.He said: &ldquoEverybody shared the view that whilst there are positive elements in the Chequers proposal, the suggested framework for economic cooperation will not work, not least because it risks undermining the single market.Mrs May fired back at the comments in her Downing Street speech and said: &ldquoYesterday Donald Tusk said our proposals would undermine the single market.&ldquoHe didn&rsquot explain how, in any detail or make any counter proposal so we are at an impasse.

title: Brexit news Jeremy Corbyn second referendum vote latest Liverpool Labour Party Conference
story: Angry Liverpudlian Neil Barrow tore into activists campaigning for a second Brexit referendum, insisting the word of the people had come out in favour of Leave.Mr Barrow expressed his indignation at the outrageous proposal after the Labour&nbspParty overwhelmingly&nbspvoted in favour of opening up a path to a new referendum if Theresa May fails to deliver a satisfactory deal.He told Express: We&rsquove had the one vote, we voted out. If that is the word of the people, that should be it. That&rsquos an outrage, absolute outrage that is.When everyone voted for it, the people who voted out didn&rsquot expect it to take this long. They just expected it to be done and get on with life normally.                Labour member sparks ROARING APPLAUSE in speech against bloc                Jeremy Corbyn SPEECH: Read the Labour leader's speech in FULL Mr Barrow appeared upbeat about the prospects independence from the European Union holds for the UK, saying that the country will march on whatever happens after March 2019.He continued: It&rsquos not going to be the end of the world because we&rsquore going out. We&rsquoll march on.Asked whether he was concerned about Jeremy Corbyn entering Number 10, he added: Yes, it concerns me.Labour delegates on Tuesday voted in a majority to keep the option of a fresh Brexit vote &ldquoon the table during the party&rsquos annual conference in Liverpool.Brexit news: Mr Barrow said he felt  (Image: EXPRESS.CO.UK&bullBBC)Shadow Brexit secretary Sir&nbspKeir Starmer&nbspsaid the party leadership had not ruled out the possibility of Labour campaigning for the option to remain in the EU to be included in a possible second referendum ballot paper.But shadow chancellor John McDonnell had previously dismissed altogether the possibility of a new vote, arguing that a fresh referendum would &ldquoide the country again.Addressing the conference on Wednesday, Mr Corbyn insisted Labour would not overturn Brexit but questioned the conduct of the May Government during the negotiations with Brussels.Mr Corbyn said: &ldquoLabour respects the decision of the British people in the referendum but no one can respect the conduct of the government since that vote took place.As it stands, Labour will vote against the Chequers plan or whatever is left of it and oppose leaving the EU with no deal. And it is inconceivable that we should crash out of Europe with no deal &ndash that would be a national disaster.That is why if Parliament votes down a Tory deal or the government fails to reach any deal at all we would press for a general election. Failing that, all options are on the table. Brexit is about the future of our country and our vital interests.Additional reporting by Darren Hunt and Jodie Packwood in Liverpool.&nbsp

title: lily allen calais apology refugee film
story: The 31-year-old broke down in tears as she visited a refugee camp in Calais in 2016, which was filmed as part of the Victoria Derbyshire show on the BBC.In the clip she said: &ldquoI apologise on behalf of my country, I&rsquom sorry for what we&rsquove put you through.She then burst into tears while interviewing a 13-year-old Afghan boy.Following the film, she received a backlash online with one social media user telling her to &ldquoput away the crocodile tears and speak for herself.                Jonathan Ross Show: Lily Allen reveals dad Keith&rsquos anger at drug claim                ITV Loose Women: Lily Allen slammed for &lsquohardly speaking&rsquo in interviewLily has apologised for comment she made during a BBC documentary segment when she visited the Calai (Image: BBC)But in her new memoirs published this month, titled My Thoughts Exactly, she wrote: &ldquoIt was a clumsy thing to say.I wanted to say, &lsquoI&rsquom sorry,&rsquo and I wanted to acknowledge that I was part of the problem, and that we are all part of the problem if we don&rsquot do more to help.&ldquoThe words came out badly, and for that I felt foolish. I was embarrassed about putting it like that.&ldquoI can be a moron. But my intentions were straightforward and without any agenda. I just wanted to help, in whatever tiny way I could.Lily said her heart was in the right place when she made the comments in 2016 (Image: BBC)She also wrote how online bullying had gone &ldquooff the charts following her comments, and revealed how haters even targeted her children.Speaking on Loose Women on Monday, Ms Allen said that she had written the memoirs in order to explain to her children why she had made certain choices when they were small.Allen told the programme: &ldquoA lot of the decisions that I made when my children were really, really small will have a lasting effect on them.&ldquoAnd if I don&rsquot tell them the truth then they will internalise those feelings of neglect or whatever it was and I think that I&rsquod rather that they know that it was mummy&rsquos fault rather than think &lsquoit&rsquos my fault&rsquo.                Lily Allen claims she has NO space for refugees in luxury London flat                Lily Allen near tears as she is 'robbed' of Mercury Prize - VIDEOLily Allen opened up about her new book on Loose Women this week (Image: ITVLOOSEWOMEN)During her visit to the camp, which was dubbed &ldquothe Calais Jungle, Ms Allen asked the Afghan teenager why a teenager left his home country for Europe, to which the boy replies: &ldquoThe Taliban were going to kill me, they were on one side and Daesh were on the other, my father sold land and sent me here.The award-winning singer then tells the teenager he has a &ldquolegal right to be in the UK and asks if he has started the process of applying to enter the UK legally.The boy replies: &ldquoThe legal process is very slow, you wait for at least three or four months. It&rsquos too slow. The way I am trying works better.Allen replied: &ldquoIt just seems that at three different intervals in this young boy&rsquos life, the English have put you in danger.&ldquoWe&rsquove bombed your country, put you in the hands of the Taliban and now putting you at risk, risking your life to get into our country.

title: Brexit news Jacob Rees Mogg blue passport UK EU withdrawal Michel Barnier latest today
story: The British Government announced in early September the beloved blue passport will be issued again from late 2019, mere months after Brexit become official on March 29.Jacob Rees-Mogg admitted the return of the iconic document was a symbolically important aspect of leaving the European Union.Speaking exclusively to Express, the North Somerset MP said: Symbolically that&rsquos a bit of fun, a cherry on the icing. Not that I much like cherries, as it happens.But I think the real excitement is that we will be in charge of our own destiny and frankly I&rsquod rather be in charge of my own destiny the leave it to Monsieur Barnier, however clever and sophisticated he may be.                De La Rue lost to GERMAN firm as well as French contract winners                Brexit blue passports to return NEXT YEAR - this is how they'll be The announcement of the return of the blue passport was marred in April when British company De La Rue said it would not appeal the decision to award the production of the ID document to French-Durch firm Gemalto.&nbspGemalto&rsquos bid of &pound260m offers the Government the possibility of saving &pound140m of taxpayers&rsquo money, compared to the &pound400m deal awarded to De La Rue in 2009.Despite public backlash, the Home Office stood by the decision to give Gemalto the 11-and-a-half year contract starting from 2019.The government has claimed that this new passport will be one of the most secure in the world with security features and technologies to protect against fraud and forgery.Brexit news: Mr Rees-Mogg said the return of the blue passport is the  (Image: &bullEXPRESS.CO.UK)With regards to the change, Immigration Minister Brandon Lewis said: &ldquoLeaving the EU gives us a unique opportunity to restore our national identity and forge a new path for ourselves in the world.That is why I am delighted to announce that the British passport will be returning to the iconic blue and gold design after we have left the European Union in 2019.It will also be one of the most secure travel documents in the world, with a raft of new security measures to protect against fraud and forgery.The Government's included the details of the return of the passport in its Brexit technical notices, warning travellers with less than six months on their existing passport may be denied entry to countries in the EU in the event of a no deal.The document also said UK citizens who plan to travel to the Schengen area after 29 March, 2019, should ensure their passports have longer than six months validity.

story: Steve Schwarzman had a warning for Theresa May about Brexit (Image: )Steve Schwarzman, chief executive of Blackstone, also expressed concern about the &ldquorisk of investing in the UK and asked &ldquohow bad can things get?.Mrs May gave a speech at the Bloomberg Business Forum in New York, where she announced her plans to slash corporation tax after leaving the EU in the hopes of reassuring business leaders.In a question and answer session after, Mr Schwarzman asked: &ldquoThings could really go off with a bad Brexit and also a change of Government.&ldquoThe things that we really worry about is how bad can things get? title: horoscope daily 2018 astrology scientific star sign
story: Horoscope daily predictions are SCIENTIFIC, psychologist believes (Image: )A study from 2017 found more than 70 percent of the global population do not believe in astrology, but one psychiatrist Ben Hayden feels the majority could be wrong on their views.This is because research has found that the time of the year in which you are born does effect your personality.Dr Hayden has pieced together global studies of personality traits which correlate with the time of the year in which one is born.Dr Hayden states that the season in which you are born effects your body&rsquos capability to fight off mental and physical ailments.                What is a Harvest Moon? Does it have a spiritual meaning?For example, those born in winter and early spring months are more likely to suffer from schizophrenia, while those who were born from April through to July have an increased chance of being dyslexic, he said.The psychiatrist also rounded up global studies to conclude that the month in which you are born does effect your personality, as astrology and horoscopes do.Dr Hayden wrote in a blog post for website Psychology Today: &ldquoA Japanese study found that people born December through February have lower agreeableness (this term has a precise definition to personality psychologists).&ldquoA Swedish study found that (at least in women), FebruaryMarchApril birthdays led to increased novelty-seeking behaviour.&ldquoAnother study reported that summer-born males are less conscientious (another term with a formal meaning).While this theory does not necessarily support astrology, Dr Hayden adds, it does add evidence that horoscope could potentially based on real science.He added: &ldquoWhen someone says there's no possible way the month you are born could have any influence on your personality, they aren't exactly correct. (Image: )On the other hand, many scientists, including those at NASA believe astrology and horoscopes are nonsense.On astrology, NASA wrote on its website: &ldquoIt's not science. No one has shown that astrology can be used to predict the future or describe what people are like based only on their birth date.

title: south africa land seizures land grab farm Cyril Ramaphosa ANC UN speech
story: Mr Ramaphosa, who is also the leader of South Africa's ruling African National Congress (ANC), defended the much-debated reform during a panel with former US president Bill Clinton and other world leaders in New York.He said: &ldquoWe're trying to undo what was set in place by colonialists.&ldquoOne of the reasons the ANC was formed was to deal with the land issue.&ldquoIt is the wound and salt in the hearts and minds of South Africans. It's a festering sore.&nbsp                South Africa ow ESCALATES as Ramaphosa calls Trump &lsquoill-informed'The ANC has since voiced its desire to redistribute the land across all the South African population.The country&rsquos 1913 Natives Land Act gave 93 percent of the farmland to white farmers, despite white colonialists being a minority in the country.To date, privately-held farmland owned by white South Africans accounts for 72 percent, with only four percent of it owned by black South Africans, according to government figures.White South Africans in the country make up just 8.2 percent of the population, while black South Africans account for 80 percent of the population.&nbsp                The truth about South Africa's land reform and farm murders                South Africa farm seizures: Ramaphosa warns UN 'land will be shared bySouth Africa land reform: Cyril Ramaphosa took part to an event with Bill Clinton (Image: EPA)Mr Ramaphosa looks set to change this, and has even proposed earlier this year a bill that would have allowed the government to seize land from white farmers without compensation.Following a major backlash, the proposal was dropped, but the ANC still stand by the necessity of carrying out a land reform.In a statement, the party said: &ldquoThe expropriation of land without compensation as one of the measures to ensure that land reform is implemented in a way that increases agricultural production, improves food security and ensures that the land is returned to those...from whom it was taken under colonialism and apartheid.The measure sparked an even wider debate when US President Donald Trump wrote on Twitter on August 22: &ldquoI have asked Secretary of State @SecPompeo to closely study the South Africa land and farm seizures and expropriations and the large scale killing of farmers.&nbspSouth Africa land reform: Cyril Ramaphosa speaking to the UN General Assembly yesterday (Image: )&lsquoSouth African Government is now seizing land from white farmers.&rsquoMr Ramaphosa branded Mr Trump &ldquoill-informed during the David Rockefeller memorial lecture delivered at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York on Monday.He said: &ldquoWell, I regret to say, I think President Trump was ill-informed about what is happening in South Africa.&ldquoAnd I think if he had taken the time to get better information from us, he would have been much better informed and his comments would have been better appreciated by South Africans.&nbsp&nbsp

title: jezza may snap election brexit
story: Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn is so desperate for a fresh election he will swallow his lelong hatred of the EU and support a second referendum.And Tory PM Theresa May would rather call a snap ­election than have another Brexit poll.So, despite Downing Street denials, it looks as  we are lurching towards a showdown which risks 1,000 years of British democracy.For be in no doubt, a Corbyn election victory and a Marxist-led Momentum regime would fundamentally change our way of le, our economy and the social fabric of this nation.Even a coalition with other parties would hand Momentum anarchists control over crucial levers of power.This week’s Labour conference in Liverpool is a Jezza rally, with far-left cheerleaders clamouring to bring down the Tories.Almost 90 per cent want a second referendum. Until now, Jezza — a staunch Bennite eurosceptic — has resisted any move to overturn Brexit. Yesterday, in a remarkable U-turn, he vowed to accept whatever delegates say.So abject surrender to the mob is the price he will pay to destroy Theresa May. “I enjoy being leader,” he said yesterday. “I am carrying on as leader of the Labour Party because I want to win an election.”His persistence in the face of scathing personal ratings is the only glint of sunlight for stricken Tories.Under any other leader, even snooty wannabe Emily Thornberry, Labour would be miles ahead.But we have learned not to underestimate Corbyn.The People’s Vote movement probably has the numbers in Parliament to vote down any deal Mrs May brings back from Brussels.These so-called “moderates”, including the slippery Peter Mandelson, leadership flop David Miliband and decrepit Vince Cable, should be careful what they wish for.In normal times, the Tories would beat off the Momentum marauders. But for all her brave talk in Downing Street last week, Mrs May is a real political liability.She destroyed both her credibility and her majority in last year’s unforced contest.The public mood on Brexit is volatile and unpredictable.Most people believe the majority for Brexit, fuelled by EU arrogance and plain bad manners, could actually grow. But nobody’s sure.A snap election would focus the public’s attention on the choice between a clean break and a botched compromise which will never be acceptable to all sides.It could cauterise the issue which still ides families and friends. Or it could backfire badly.Tory Brexiteers must think hard before pulling the plug on the Maybot. It could split their party asunder.But so could Jeremy Corbyn’s rank opportunism.Blairite Labour moderates must soon choose.If they help Jeremy Corbyn win a vote of no confidence, what do they do next?Will they campaign for a party whose rampant extremists wish them dead? Will they stay silent while Momentum activists unseat their moderate comrades?Can deputy Tom Watson support a leader whose own MPs need round-the-clock armed guards against his dangerously fanatical supporters?Can they ignore threats of rape and torture? Nothing is too extreme or too petty for these thugs. They even want ex-Labour luvvie Maureen Lipman sacked from Corrie for attacking their Beloved Leader.Anyone who thinks images of Marxist anarchy are far-fetched should listen to Corbyn sidekick Dawn Butler praising the 1980s Militant Tendency — the forerunner to Momentum — which almost bankrupted Merseyside.“We are in Liverpool where over 30 years ago the council stood up to Thatcher and said, better to break the law than break the poor,” she ranted.That was when Labour split asunder for the first time, creating a new Social Democrat party which posed a short-lived threat the Tories.Roy Hattersley, deputy leader in those turbulent times, warns the party could split again today. “All we need is for one of the hard-working, long-suffering MPs to be kicked out and the whole thing will blow up in our faces,” he said yesterday.The Tories just need to be patient.Albanian drug gangs are gaining market share from Bulgarians, Romanians and Colombians by slashing cocaine prices.Police arrested a record 4,000 peddlers operating across county lines, mostly too young to charge.Kne crime among Somalis, Eritreans and Nigerians is soaring.Meanwhile, there’s a growth spurt in modern slavery.Organised crime is a multi-billion-pound industry affecting “more UK citizens, more often, than any other national security threat,” says the National Crime Agency.All despite Brexit.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pm focus on brexit not election
story: Rumours of a snap election in November, just four months before we leave the EU, are deeply concerning.Not only does it give the impression of a Government in chaos, it would cost Britain valuable negotiating time.Decision time is quickly approaching for Theresa May.“Brexit means Brexit” will soon need flesh added to the bones: the Chequers compromise or the more ambitious — but more dficult to deliver — model presented by free traders today.And far from pondering her domestic strength, she should focus on flexing her muscles with Brussels.Above all, it means reminding that unconvincing Napoleon tribute act Emmanuel Macron and the tight-fisted Angela Merkel that we’re perfectly happy to break free without paying a penny of our £39billion “exit deal”.They must know that asking their own increasingly Eurosceptic voters to fill the hole left by our departure could bring down the whole house of cards.And keeping that cash here would pay for plenty of tax cuts, making the UK even more competitive on a global stage.It’s time to get tough. Deal, or no dough.LABOUR’S position on Brexit is clear as mud, but we know one thing they do believe: the Press needs muzzling.From the moment Jeremy Corbyn told us that “change is coming”, the media has come under attack after attack from a leader who is playing the man — not the ball — when it comes to those asking him legitimate questions.Union strongman Len McCluskey accused the media of “vicious attacks” on the Labour Party.But it’s not an “attack” to ask Corbyn, a man who wants to be PM, why he spent his holidays visiting a terrorists’ cemetery in Tunisia or why he invited the IRA for tea and treats in Parliament.Nor is it just the tactics of the hated “mainstream media” to ask John McDonnell whether his extremist economics will actually work in the real world..Today’s announcement on employee ownership appears appealing for workers, but it would only hit investment and productivity in the long-term.If this Labour Party gains power, the free Press — and the economy — would be in serious danger.IS Anthony Joshua now the UK’s most impressive sportsman?His win over Alexander Povetkin at a packed-out Wembley was stunning.It’s now on to Fury and Wilder.Beat those two, and he might go down as Britain’s best ever boxer.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jane moore katie price rehab romance
story: The second time was in January 2016, behind the scenes of Loose Women.In the intervening years, I had made several waspish remarks about her on this very page  so fully expected a frosty exchange.But she was disarmingly self-deprecating, funny and, to my utter surprise, very much a woman’s woman.“I know you think I’m a nightmare,” she said matter-of-factly. “And you’re probably right. But I think we’re going to get on.”She was right. We did. The other panellists liked her too.Predominantly mothers, we treated her as one might a naughty niece you were particularly fond of, rolling our eyes and smiling affectionately as she regaled us with the latest relationship drama in her le.But despite her no-nonsense, often humorous delivery, there was always a faint “here we go again” sadness behind her eyes and, as I saw it, a low self-esteem that might explain the constant cosmetic alterations and propensity to criticise herself before anyone else could.After reading the recent headlines of wild nights out and rap songs about cocaine, it’s easy to think that Katie is a party girl who has largely abandoned her children as an inconvenience to the carefree lestyle she longs to have.And, judging by yesterday’s letters page, plenty of you do.Before getting to know her, I might have shared that view. But now I see her admittedly destructive behaviour as a cry for help and I’m relieved that, finally, she’s in to rehab to get it.Once, in a rare flash of what I feel is the real Katie, she told me that her Holy Grail was to find a decent, dependable man who could pay the bills while she stayed home and ran a large, chaotic farmhouse full of children and animals.Her favourite night of the week was Friday, when she would wipe off her “work face”, slip in to her old trackie bottoms and call in a takeaway for her, her now estranged third husband Kieran and the kids.Anyone who has seen her interacting with Harvey, her severely disabled eldest son, will know that she’s a fundamentally devoted mother doing her best  in often trying circumstances.Remember her in the I’m A Celebrity jungle? Free of make-up, her hair in braids, tackling each challenge with an admirably no-nonsense bravado? To my mind, that’s the real Katie — the rest is just noise.But without doubt, she has a self-destructive streak when she feels let down.So, after catching Kieran having an affair with her “best friend”, forgiving him, then catching him again with someone else, it was inevitable that a fall was coming. Her mum Amy said at the weekend: “Kate has been her own worst enemy and behaved like an idiot at times but she has been tearing herself apart for years.“All the men in her le have used Katie, and never, ever leave her alone . . . Kieran almost destroyed Kate with his behaviour, Alex  has been as bad, and Pete  likes to portray himself as perfect . . . they all know that  they wind her up, she will react.“Kate is stupid for reacting, but these men need to look at how they are behaving and take some responsibility.”Wise words. And Katie needs to heed them as much as her former husbands.She’s always been disarmingly frank about the incidents in her le that would have sent many of us over the edge — not least being sexually abused when she was just six years old. But now it’s time for her to stop shrugging them off as “just one of those things” and take a long, hard look at how they’ve shaped her often destructive behaviour patterns as an adult.I hope she sticks with the therapy and, ultimately, finds contentment.HOT on the stilettos of Stormy Daniels’ lurid description of Donald Trump’s manhood, singer Cher has been regaling us with tales of her former lovers.Tom Cruise is in her “top five” but legendary lothario Warren Beatty was, apparently, a disappointment.Cher, 72, explains: “Not that he wasn’t technically good, but I didn’t feel anything.”We remain blissfully unaware of whether she means emotionally or physically.EAGLE-EYED travellers boarding a flight operated by Hong Kong airline Cathay Pacic noticed this glaring spelling error on the side of the plane.Though it grieves me greatly, spelling errors or “typos” are now commonplace in everyday exchanges via text, tweet or email, but it never ceases to amaze me when they’re writ large on something as expensive as a sign, billboard or, er, Boeing 747.Does no one check these things before literally advertising their ignorance? Seems not.And so, we are entertained by such gems as Shoplters Will Be Prostituted, Chris Is Risen, All Busniesses Open As Usual, Pay and Display Apples In This Area, Costumers Only, Parrallel Parking, No Trough Road and Pedestrain Crossing, to name but a few.And don’t even get me started on missing or misplaced apostraffy’s…WHEN cookery presenter Nadiya Hussain was picked to bake the Queen’s birthday cake in 2016, she recalls feeling that it was an opportunity to act against Islamophobia.“Everybody thinks it, ‘Oh God, who let the Muslim woman near the Queen with a kne?’” she says now. “Let’s address that elephant in the room, because they did.”Nope. Actually, I remember thinking, “Oh, it’s that lovely woman who won Bake Off and made Mary Berry cry tears of joy”.Sorry to disappoint, Nadiya.Quite right too.Particularly as the majority of them are now more recognisable than the “celebrities” they’re dancing with.HOLLYWOOD director Sam Mendes says his now defunct marriage to Kate Winslet struggled because he “was not very comfortable being married to a celebrity . . . it made me feel self-conscious”.Couldn’t he have worked that out before they trotted down the aisle?VIDEO game designers are working on giving avatars real-le emotions to make the experience more authentic.Will they include a frustrated parent yelling: “Get off that bloody thing before you turn in to someone with the physical and people skills of an atrophied three-toed sloth?No, thought not.ACTRESS Helena Bonham Carter says she used a psychic to contact Princess Margaret so she could perfect her role as the Queen’s sister in the forthcoming third series of The Crown.She claims Margaret told her she’s “doing a great job”.Hmmm. From what little one knows of the feisty royal, “fack orf” seems more likely.FRANK SPRINGETT is 91, his we Mary is 86 and they have been married for 67 years.Frank is deaf and suffers from arthritis, Mary has severe Alzheimer’s, and both are being looked after in the same Warwickshire-based care home using funds from the sale of their house.However, the money is now running low and while social services will continue to partially pay for Mary’s care, it says former factory worker Frank has to look after himself.Meaning that 70 years after they met, they face being separated for the first time.“We fear  they are torn apart, the strain will kill them,” says their daughter Joanne, 57.With seemingly endless funds being readily shelled out to help accommodate those  who seek asylum in Britain, how sad that someone who has paid in to the system all their le gets so let down when they need it most.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: passenger goair india open plane door toilet
story: The man, in his late 20s, was travelling on a GoAir flight from New Delhi to Patna in India on Saturday when he urgently needed the bathroom.Local media reported that passengers were screaming while cabin crew wrestled the man away from the door and ordered him to remain in his seat for the rest of his flight.He was was escorted from the plane by airport security upon arrival and handed over to police, who quizzed him about his motives and he admitted it was a mistake.Sanowar Khan, the officer in charge of the local police, said the man caused pandemonium when he tried to open the rear door.Khan told Kolkata-based newspaper The : “People asked him why he was doing so .He told them that he needed to use the washroom urgently and kept tugging at the exit door.Pandemonium prevailed amid all this and he was restrained and finally handed over to us.He said that the confusion happened because he had boarded a flight for the first time in his le.”Khan added that the man, who is a banker and was flying for the first time, was released without charge.He said: There was no ulterior motive behind this act.A GoAir spokesperson said the 1hr 45min flight, which was carrying 150 passengers, landed safely in Patna at 7.35pm on Saturday.They said: “A passenger on flight G8 149 Del-Pat was trying to open the rear door of the aircraft while in the air.“A co-passenger raised the alarm and he was intercepted by the crew. Post arrival, the passenger was handed over to CISF  for further investigation.”The security force, which is part of the Indian military, told the Times of India the man had managed to unlock the rear door but couldnt open it due to cabin pressure.

title: brussels eu press regulation sun
story: Justice commissioner Vera Jourova was riled by our front page labelling EU leaders “dirty rats” over their tactics.She accused the UK media of spreading “disinformation” and suggested “smart regulation”.Speaking in Austria, Ms Jourova said: “Media can build the culture of dialogue or sow isions, spread disinformation and encourage exclusion.“The Brexit debate is the best example of that. Do you remember the front page of a popular British daily calling the judges the ‘enemy of the people’?Or just last week, the EU leaders were called ‘dirty rats’ on another front page.Almost daily we could find examples of stories that are spiced up to point out the enemy, to paint the picture black and white.I would advocate for a European approach to media based on quality and smart regulation,  needed.But Tory MEP Amjad Bashir said: “Commissioners should not be trying to shackle the Press.“We politicians do not always like what journalists write, but they have to be free to report the news as they see it.The vibrancy and iety of our newspapers is one of the things that makes Britain great.People have to learn to take the rough with the smooth.Otherwise we are on a slippery slope to state control and oppression.Mr Bashir’s colleague Ashley Fox added: “A free and unfettered media is vital.” EU officials insisted there was no new legislative action in the pipeline in terms of media regulation and that Ms Jourova had been talking about broadcasters.A Commission spokeswoman said she was merely trying to “trigger a discussion”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
