title: michael douglas president catherine zeta jones
story: The couple, who turned 74 and 49 respectively, have been married for nearly 18 years.Jones took to Instagram last night to wish Douglas a happy birthday, calling him my very own President.The Welsh actress added clips from her husbands 1995 flick The American President in which he plays the US leader.She wrote: Happy Birthday to my very own President! My husband Michael.I guess that makes me First Lady! Stranger things have happened! Go figure.Oops, its my birthday today too.Douglas has worked for the UN for years, serving as a United Nations Messenger of Peace since 1998 and is the longest serving holder of the position.He has been a long-time supporter of the Democratic Party and a vocal advocate of gun control and nuclear non-proleration.Despite his contrary political views to the current occupant of The White House he has in the past described Donald Trump as a friend.While Trump was running in 2016 the Wall Street star said of the then candidate: I know him personally and hes a charming guy - I play golf with him and he’s got a very good self-effacing sense of humour.I dont agree with him politically but I think hes set a tone thats attracted a certain set of our population, Im just not sure how much its going to grow before the election.However he added: Im a Democrat by le, I know the Clintons pretty well, Bill when he was in office and Hillary Clinton, I think shell be a spectacular President.Meanwhile, Trumps speech at the UN yesterday drew laughter from world leaders as the US President boasted of his “extraordinary” achievements.Praising Americas booming economy, the brash billionaire said: My administration has accomplished more in two years than almost any administration in the history of our country... so true.Seemingly taken aback by his boast, the audience broke into laughter, prompting a smiling Trump to say: “I wasnt expecting that reaction but thats OK.

title: royal mail walkers crisp packets
story: Baffled postal workers keep finding the litter in letterboxes without envelopes addressed to Walkers freepost address.It turns out that eco-warriors have been sending the bags back to the crisp makers as a protest against its use of non-recyclable packets.A campaign on the petition website 38 Degrees called on Leicestershire-based Walkers to ditch plastic packaging.It reads: We call upon Walkers and other manufacturers to change the materials for their packets to one which is recyclable or even more preferably a non-plastic environmentally friendly material.The petition was later bolstered by a separate post on the site titled #PacketInWalkers - Post your plastic packet back to Walkers.It called on the hundreds of thousands of campaign backers to join in a cunning plan to make the crisp giant pay attention to their environmentally friendly cause.But Royal Mail are begging people to stop posting the packets without an envelope because they are causing delays.A spokesperson told the BBC: We strongly encourage customers not to post anything in the postal system which is not properly packaged.Crisp packets cant go through the machines, they are not normal mail items therefore my hardworking colleagues need to manually sort them, which adds to time.But green activists have taken to social media using the campaign hashtag to tell Walkers to change its ways, even though it has previously committed to using compostable or biodegradable packaging by 2025.The 38 Degrees Twitter account posted: By the time @walkers_crisps goes plastic free in 2025 theyll have produced 28 billion more bags of crisps.310,000 think this isnt good enough - so 38 Degrees members are posting their crisp packets back to Walkers. #PacketInWalkers.Walkers have confirmed that they have received some of the ed packets and will use them for research.A spokesperson said: We recognise the efforts being made to bring the issue of packaging waste to our attention.

title: mh370 plane is in a thousand pieces at the bottom of the indian ocean in an unexplored zone new documentary claims
story: The Malaysian Airlines plane disappeared without a trace on March 2014 on a flight from Kuala Lumpor to Beijing, killing all 239 people on board.National Geographic’s Drain the Oceans series has now, with the help of experts, pinned what it thinks is the jets likely location and what the wreckage would look like on the ocean floor.The programme says the plane is located at around 35 degrees south on a line known as the seventh arc, in reference to the last time MH370 sent a satellite message.Using computer graphics it has “drained” the area around the seventh arc to reveal what the wreckage of the aircraft could look like.The debris will stretch over thousands of yards, it says, and while the engines will be in one piece, the fuselage will be in thousands.Drain the Oceans says blackboxes will reveal  anyone was in the cockpit at the end and oxygen cylinders will show  the plane was deliberately depressurised in flightPersonal electronic devices could reveal the experiences and fate of inidual passengers and crew.Andy Sherrell, an undersea search specialist who has taken part in the hunt for MH370 and found the wrecks of other aircraft underwater, says the moment it is found will be “sombre”.“It’s a really surreal sombre moment because you realise all of a sudden you’ve found this grave site, this place where all these people persished,” Sherrell told the programme.“It’s sad but it’s also a bit of a relief because you know from that point forward some answers are going to come back.”The exact location was arrived at by oceanographer David Grfin using wreckage found thousands of miles away.He believes the flapperon which was found on the French island of Reunion holds the key to finding the location of MH370.Dr Grfin conducted an experiment using an identical flapperon off a Boeing 777 and using data about currents in the Indian Ocean was able to map its 500 day journey across the sea.He was also curious about why no debris had been washed up in Australia when currents in the area where the plane crashed flow towards the country.The scientist was able to rule out areas on the seventh arc where the current flows towards Australia as a possible crash site.Dr Grfin looked at the data for the currents that exists for the day MH370 crashed and pinpointed where on the seventh arc currents would have pushed debris away from Australia towards Africa.Only one of the locations on the seventh arc matched his calculation of the flapperon’s journey – 35 degrees south.The area was not checked during the initial surface search for the wreckage of the plane.His view that MH370 crashed there was backed by images from a French military satellite taken 15 days after the plane’s disappearance showing possible debris on the surface in the 35 south area.“I remember the day when I first saw those images in high resolution and I thought ‘oh my God’,” he said.Beginning in January this year a search was mounted in that area by a privately funded expedition run by salvage company Ocean Infinity.But despite searching an enormous area, the expedition found no trace of MH370.The search has now covered an area 14 times that scoured in the hunt for Air France flight 447, which crashed in the South Atlantic and took two years to find.In May the Malaysian government called off the search for MH370 but Drain the Oceans says it could lie tantalisingly close to the search area.“I think it’s enormously important to find the plane because while planes crash routinely they don’t just disappear and I think this just terries people,” says David Grfin.• Drain The Oceans: Malaysia  Airlines  370 airs on National Geographic this Thursday, 27 September at 8pm.

title: emma dent coad royal family charity work
story: Emma Dent Coad said the royal family’s support for charity is only “peripheral” and claimed volunteers do “99 per cent of the work”.She has previously claimed Prince Harry can’t really fly a helicopter despite his military record.And she said Princess Diana would disapprove of her own sons lavish wedding - while calling for the National Anthem to be scrapped, and comparing the royals to the Kardashians.The tirade comes just days after the Duchess of Sussex launched a new initiative to help victims of the Grenfell Tower disaster who live in the MP’s constituency.Speaking at the Labour conference in Liverpool, Ms Dent Coad also:The Corbynista MP laid in to the royal family at a fringe meeting hosted by pressure group Labour For A Republic.She claimed the Grenfell “atrocity” has turned the public against the status quo by exposing inequality across the UK.Ms Dent Coad then said: “I know some people find it really encouraging when members of the royal family support local charities - people have told me ‘So and so came in, they helped us with this, and it was really encouraging.’“I don’t have any problem with that at all, but when the cameras are gone let’s remember those volunteers are back doing 99 per cent of the work completely unsung, completely unappreciated.“Their support is important to some, not to others, but its peripheral.”Last week Prince Harry’s we Meghan launched a charity cookbook written with the survivors of Grenfell Tower.She took her mum Doria and Harry to meet the women who wrote recipes for the book at an event at Kensington Palace - located in Ms Dent Coad’s constituency.As well as her dig at royal charity work, the MP hit out at the Queen’s tax arrangements.She said: “She pays tax only on one thing which is the income from her grace and favour properties, the properties that she lets out. So she pays tax on that, nothing else, just that.“She doesnt pay tax on anything else. And as we know she also has some money offshore, so thats disappointing.”In fact, the monarch voluntarily pays tax on all her private income whatever its source.Ms Dent Coad has a track record of angry rants at the royal family.At the same event at last year’s Labour conference, she sparked fury by claiming Prince Harry is unable to fly a helicopter.EMMA Dent Coad became Kensington’s first Labour MP at last year’s General Election, winning the seat by just 20 votes.But she is a longstanding opponent of her constituency’s best-known residents - Princes William and Harry, who both live in Kensington Palace with their wives.Ms Dent Coad is such an ardent republican she even held an anti-royal picnic on the day William married Kate in 2011.And since entering Parliament she has continued slagging off the royals in a string of public rants.The Sun revealed at last year’s Labour conference that she accused Harry of being unable to fly a helicopter.Ms Dent Coad claimed that whenever the prince gets in a chopper, “He just sits there going ‘vroom vroom’.”She’s also compared the Middleton family to the Kardashian clan, dubbing the Duchess of Cambridge “Kate Kardashian”.The MP caused offence ahead of Harry and Meghan’s wedding this year by saying Princess Diana would be upset by the public attention paid to the nuptials.And speaking on the day of the ceremony, Ms Dent Coad called for the National Anthem to be scrapped because it’s “jingoistic”.

title: happiest places to live britain life satisfaction
story: Brits have been asked to rate their well-being and le satisfaction, with some parts of the country producing happier residents than others.The Office for National Statistics  has upgraded its regular survey of well being by asking residents four questions to determine  they are happy.People were quizzed on how satisfied they are are with their le, to what extent they feel the things they do in their le are worthwhile, how happy they felt yesterday and how anxious they felt yesterday?To answer, those in the survey had to give a personal score out of 10.Overall the UK scored 7.7 out of 10 for le satisfaction, 7.9 out of 10 for feeling worthwhile, 7.5 out of 10 for happiness yesterday and 2.9 out of 10 for feeling anxious yesterday.Rushmoor in Hampshire came out as the happiest place to live, with the people living there scoring it 8.34 out of 10.Whereas those living in Fenland in Cambridgeshire are less enthusiastic about their le there, scoring their happiness level at 6.7 out of 10.Copeland in Cumbria is second ranked in the happiest places in the UK, with a score of 8.24 out of 10.But exclusive Kensington and Chelsea, one of the UKs wealthiest areas, scored low and came in as the second unhappiest place to live.Northern Ireland saw the highest average le satisfaction and happiness ratings when compared with Wales, Scotland and England.And people in London reported a lower average sense that things they do in le are worthwhile.It was also found women reported a higher level of anxiety than man.Silvia Manclossi, Head of Quality of Le Team, Office for National Statistics said: “An important part of our work is looking beyond the economic health of the country to how its people are faring and inequalities in society.Today, for the first time, we have identied how factors such as health, access to services, and crime levels may affect how people rate their well-being in dferent parts of the UK.This can help local authorities and other organisations to better understand where services could be targeted to help improve the well-being of people in their area.”He said earlier in the year: There is a growing recognition that how we are doing as a nation is at least as much about people’s well-being as it is about the country’s economic health.Today’s analysis shows the strengths and challenges of dferent age groups in society.These insights can help target services where they are most needed and can have the best impact.

title: forget everything on a night out how to stop a booze blackout before it happens
story: Apart from it being a pretty terrying experience leaving you consumed with fear the next day, blacking out in a booze-induced stupor can have an alarming effect on the body.Blackouts are a gap in the tape of your memory, said George Koob, director of the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism.He told HuffPo that in a blackout, alcohol shuts down the ability of the brain to consolidate memories.Well, it doesnt mean that someone becomes unconscious.As anyone whos humiliated themselves on a night out might know, people tend to continue interacting with other people and engaging in potentially embarrassing or dangerous activities even after their brains have buzzed off.Of course, you can pass out during a blackout - and thats the most dangerous thing about them, with the possibility of sustaining a head injury from falling, choking on vomit or getting alcohol poisoning.But  your mates still compus mentus, then it can be tricky to tell whether theyre approaching blackout mode or not.Theres no definitive guide to blacking out - symptoms can dfer from person to person, or session by session.But common signs that someones very drunk include poor coordination, vomiting or needing help to get home.However there are some signs to watch out for, including:Source: American Addiction Centres“Slurred speech is also common, and people are sensitive to that it’s why police use it as a test,” explained Koob.“Also, same with motor coordination. They might be bumping into things. It’s hard to walk in a straight line when you’re that intoxicated.”A change in personality is also a pretty good indicator, Koob said.One marker I use is dramatic and rapid swings in emotionality.“One moment, your friend might be praising you and telling you how much they care. The next, they turn, and it’s the complete opposite emotion, like anger directed at you.”Its an obvious answer but the key is to drink in moderation - both to protect your dignity and your long-term health.According to Alcohol Concern, excessive drinking is the biggest risk factor for death, ill-health and disability among 15-49 year-olds in the UK - and is the fth biggest factor among all ages.To reduce your chances of developing a whole host of potentially fatal diseases, Public Health England is encouraging middle-aged drinkers to have at least two days a week off the booze.A study from the University of Calornia, San Diego, claimed to have found that around 40 per cent of brains are more prone to blackouts from booze and drugs than others.Well, its all to do with ethanol - a compound found in alcohol.Drinking up to four boozy drinks in a short space of time can heighten its effects - particularly  youve not eaten much.When the stomach is empty, ethanol reaches the blood as soon as half an hour after consumption.That means that as you drink, your blood ethanol level inches high and higher for up to 90 minutes - possibly without realising just how drunk you are until youre already pretty far gone.After a couple of hours on the sauce, that ethanol then dfuses from the blood into the brain.The booze then targets receptors in the part of the brain which controls emotions and recollection, including something called the gamma-aminobutyric acid, or GABA.When GABA receptors are affected by alcohol, the brain stops transmitting signals that would otherwise solidy memories.It also helps the brain to start producing things like dopamine and serotonin, as well as glutamate - the neurotransmitter that results in your feeling calmer.Thats why you often feel amazing when youre drinking...so you drink more - all the while getting increasingly leathered.But that can also lead to you doing things which are out of character. As your inhibitions go down with that fth G&ampT, you start to think that dancing on the tables a good idea, that sexting your boss is totally legit.And the next day, you cant understand why your boss is looking at you oddly from across the office, or why youre covered in bruises from falling off the table.Its not just the damage to your ego thats the problem - blacking out means that youre drinking to excess, and that comes with all the usual health issues associated with drinking, including developing liver problems, heart disease and ious cancers.

title: jeremy corbyn speech labour party conference 2018
story: The hard left leader used his conference speech to party faithful to try to persuade Britain that he is now ready to lead the nation.The 69 year-old doubled down on his Socialist agenda by branding a series of new radical policies “the new political mainstream”.And the party boss claimed that next year’s annual party gathering in September 2019 would meet “as a Labour government”.Mr Corbyn, 69, told the audience in Liverpool that his left wing mass movement in now “ready to take charge”.And he instructed them: “We must take our message to every town, city and village. United and ready to win, ready to govern as we were in 1945, 1964 and 1997.“Let every constituency, every community know Labour is ready.”But at the same time, he also issued an appeal to his bitterly ided party’s Labour’s squabbling factions to unite.Calling on warring MPs and members to “focus on what unites us”, he pleaded: “We need to foster a much greater culture of tolerance. An end to abuse, online and in person.“We must learn to listen a bit more, and shout a lot less.”Mr Corbyn also admitted the summer had been “tough”, after he was repeatedly rocked by an MPs’ revolt over accusations that he held anti-Semitic views.But while admitting that the row “caused immense hurt and anxiety in the Jewish community”, the Labour boss refused to use his major platform to offer Jews another apology.Instead, he only added: “I hope we can work together to draw a line under it”.Mr Corbyn highlighted a series of new policy announcements made through out the four day gathering on Merseyside that have driven Labour even further to the left.They included forcing companies to hand over 10% of their worth to employees, and workers’ takeover of board rooms.He poured fresh scorn on bankers for “piling up profits around the world”.And when the Labour scornfully mentioned Theresa May’s bid to ensire the UK has the lowest corporation tax rates of all the G20 nations, the enterprise-boosting offer was booed by the packed hall.The Labour boss also issued his regular Trump-style rant at the media.JEREMY Corbyn’s speech today drew derision from the Tories - who said his plans would drown Britain in debt and risk betraying Brexit.And Jewish groups criticised the Labour leader for not explaining how he will tackle anti-Semitism. Conservative chairman Brandon Lewis said: Jeremy Corbyn has shown at every turn he is unfit to govern. All he offers are failed ideas that didnt work in the past and would leave working families paying the price with higher taxes, more debt and more waste - just like last time.He confirmed Labour are opening the door to re-running the referendum, which would take us all back to square one.And he didnt even apologise to Jewish people for his total failure to tackle the anti-Jewish racism that is re in the Labour Party.Marie van der Zyl, president of the Board of Deputies of British Jews, added: “Jeremy Corbyn’s words mean nothing until Labour takes the necessary steps to deal with anti-Semitism in its ranks.“Words have long ceased to be enough. Actions are what matter.”Unions cheered his proposals for greater state control of industry - but business groups expressed caution.The director general of the CBI, Carolyn Fairbairn, warned that policy built on ideology and diktat would harm those who can least afford it by driving down investment, productivity and pay.Federation of Small Businesses chairman Mike Cherry said: While weve heard some welcome commitments from the Labour Party in the past few days, it should more readily acknowledge the social contribution of businesses across the UK.And free-market think-tanks were also critical - Mark Littlewood of the IEA said: “Jeremy Corbyn is right to highlight that parts of the establishment have far too much control over Britain’s economy.“Westminster’s elite should not be picking winners and losers in business, or deciding whose jobs have guaranteed funding from the taxpayer.“Yet his proposals today – including the creation of 400,000 green energy jobs and increased centralisation of the National Health Service - imagine a Britain in which consumer choice is further limited, and more services are controlled by a select few in Whitehall.” John O’Connell of the Taxpayers’ Alliance added: Corbyns angry rant offered nothing to the hard-pressed, silent majority of taxpayers who want to be trusted to spend their own money and care for their children as they see fit - without being clobbered by even more cruel punishment taxes.” While pledging to protect press freedom, the then immediately insisted: “Freedom here too often means the freedom to spread lies and half truths and to smear the powerless, not take on the powerful”.And he heaped praise in Spanish on his Mexican-born we Laura Alez, telling her from the podium: “Tu eres mi fuerza y mi apoyo. Gracias Laurita ”.Business leaders reacted with horror, with the BCC saying his leftwing package would inflict “a serious impact on business confidence, investment and growth, which ultimately would hurt the very people and communities that need support the most”.Its Director General Adam Marshall added: “While there were some bright spots, Jeremy Corbyn missed a golden opportunity to extend an olive branch to British business, big and small alike”.But unions firebrands loved Mr Corbyn’s 70 minute-long diarribe. Unite general secretary ‘Red Len’ McCluskey dubbed it “*inspiring”.PCS general secretary Mark Serwotka added: Today Jeremy has set out a transformative and radical socialist vision for the country”.Veteran leftwing Labour MP Dennis Skinner was left jubilant, telling the hall: “I want to nationalise something every week”.Tory chairman Brandon Lewis said Mr Corbyn had showed that “at every turn he is unfit to govern”.It was his traditional blend of bile, fantasy and lies, falteringly recited in his two stock voices — all hammily-acted phoney compassion one moment, ­sudden exaggerated rage the next.He turned his ire first on Tories, then on a critical Press. This, he insisted, would remain free under Labour — but not just to print what it liked. Thick as he is, ­Corbyn sees no contradiction.Then it was on to Jezza curing all our ills with freebies galore and mass job creation, all presumably funded by the same tax on the rich. Since Labour aides now privately admit their 2017 manesto secretly covered up a £1TRILLION bill, Corbyn’s assurances aren’t worth the autocue they are written on.This smug, cocky Labour conference is an annual reminder of just what a dishonest rabble they now are. Sickeningly posing as defenders of the dispossessed while plotting to annul their Brexit votes with a second referendum, brought about by orchestrating chaos.One moronic MP even demanded a General Strike to oust the Government. Frontbencher Richard Burgon stood and applauded. And he is the “next Secretary of State for Justice”, God help us.Corbyn is keen to rebrand his extremism as mainstream in an era when capitalism has “failed”. It is, in reality, a dog-eared hard-left roadmap to ruin on a scale we have never experienced. A Britain which would kill ambition and enterprise and drive out successful firms by stealing their property. Where investors would fear to tread and from which anyone who could would flee.Labour’s candidate for PM is a dim, vain, vindictive, unapologetically anti­Semitic ball of rage who loathes scrutiny, lies habitually about his true beliefs and past terrorist connections and is, his aides admit, “not good in the mornings”.But the Tories must not mistake all that for a free pass. Corbyn’s plans have traction only because the Government has left the battlefield. Theresa May and Philip Hammond are timid tinkerers when we need radical steps to put more money in pockets and make homes affordable. Socialism is the last thing we need.Next to last are Tory “Corbyn-lite” tax rises. Record job figures, low inflation and interest rates add up to a society and economy far healthier than the dystopia of chippy Corbynite imaginations.But  the Tories don’t fix the problems that DO exist they’re sunk, and Britain too.Mr Lewis added: “All he offers are failed ideas that didn’t work in the past and would leave working families paying the price with higher taxes, more debt and more waste – just like last time.“He didn’t even apologise to Jewish people for his total failure to tackle the anti-Jewish racism that is re in the Labour Party.”

title: british oap sleep rough russian airport two weeks
story: In a story which has been compared to the 2004 Tom Hanks movie The Terminal, Steve Beard was banned from flying to London and was forced to wash in toilets at the travel hub.His journey to Russia began a decade ago, when he fell in love with schoolteacher Ruslana Lesyuta, then aged 42, on a dating site and moved to a village in Siberia to be with her.The Brit, who has a son Robert, eight, with his we, had intended to fly briefly back to the UK to sort out his pension payments.Steve, a former metal worker, lives in the remote Irkutsk region where winter temperatures plummet to minus 50C or below.His we claims he has struggled to adapt to le in Russia, has failed to learn the language and is unemployed.He flew to Moscow but was then barred from leaving the country at Sheremetyevo airport because his Russian residency permit had expired.“They stopped me and did not let me fly out of the country,” he told Komsomolskaya Pravda newspaper.“I was fined. And the migration service urgent me to  to Irkutsk.”Instead, Beard - who worked for 30 years in a London metals plant - flew to Pulkovo airport in St Petersburg to try and leave the country.But again he was told he could not pass through immigration and fly back to Blighty.In despair, Steve stayed in the terminal Pulkovo without money or a bank card.It was only due to help from a Russian tourism official who felt his plight was like the character played by Oscar winning actor Hanks in The Terminal that he was rescued from his ordeal.The Steven Spielberg-directed movie tells the story of an Eastern European man who becomes stranded at New York’s JFK airport after his native country is embroiled in a military coup.And just like Hanks’ character, Steve was forced to wash in the airport bathrooms and eat fast food at the restaurants in the travel hub.The Brit said: “I slept in an chair in the waiting room. I washed my face and hair in the restrooms.“I ate the cheapest food at airport diners. I do not speak Russian, so I could not earn any money here.”He pleaded from help from the British consulate and was lucky to find Ilya Tarashkevich - a sympathetic worker in the St Petersburg tourist information bureau.Ilya said: “Steve approached me and asked how a foreigner can receive a money transfer.“He did not have a card, and the bank did not work with foreigners. My colleagues and I were puzzled.“Soon I realised that the only way was to use my card.”He took pity on a man labelled an “alien” who “had not eaten for three days”.Ilya continued: “I thought what should happen in a persons le to make this happen.“Then Beard also said that he was afraid that he would be banned from entering the country again.“The most important thing in his le is his child. I am a father myself, so I understand him.“Then I decided to help Steve.”After Ilyas help scanning his documents, Steve appeared in court where he was fined around £58.However the judge understood his plight and overruled a demand to have Steve expelled from Russia after he had paid his fine.Barring the Brit from ing to Russia to see his loved ones would violate the human right to a family le, the court ruled.Steve, who married his we eight years ago, is now preparing new documents allowing him to re-enter Russia after he s from his trip to Britain.His we, who has four children from another relationship, said they had fallen in love after  chatting on the internet for three years.Ruslana, who now has a business selling window units, said their first meeting was in Ukraine.

title: traveller 21 sprayed with ammonia and had hand sliced off with machete after he was lured to meet two teen girls in feud over his sister
story: Ellie Elston, 18, and another girl aged 17 allegedly tricked Francis Doherty, 21, to meet them in West London - where Elstons boyfriend Miles Connors, 23, carried out the violent attack.Connors sprayed his former friend Mr Doherty with the corrosive substance before hacking his hand off and leaving it on the ground, Isleworth Crown Court heard.Police bodycam footage of the aftermath of the attack showed Mr Doherty screaming: “My whole hand’s on the floor. I’m dying, I’m dying”.The jury were told Connors, his brother Daniel, 19, and the two girls kidnapped Mr Dohertys 14-year-old nephew and made him call his uncle as part of the plot.Prosecutor Roger Smart said the boy was stripped naked, wiped down with bleach, dressed in girls’ clothing and told to leave London after the attack.The Evening Standard reported Mr Smart as saying: “[The boy] was told to call Francis Doherty and say that he had met two girls who are interested in meeting him.“Both [the 17-year-old] and Ellie Elston took turns speaking to Francis, enticing him to come and meet them.“They told Francis to attend alone and to look out for a white BMW.Francis agreed to join them and hurriedly made his way to the location.”The court was told Mr Dohertys and Connors families had been at war for some time after Connors made disrespectful remarks about Francis sister, Biddy Doherty.The pair had tried to sort out the problems by fighting in front of a crowd, which Mr Doherty is said to have won.But three days later Connors and his fellow defendants allegedly acted out their bloody revenge plot.With his arm mangled and fearing for his le, Mr Doherty ran behind some parked cars and saw Connors get into a Jeep style vehicle, the prosecution said.In it Mr Doherty saw his nephew, Michael Connors, staring back at him before the vehicle sped off, the jury heard.The kidnap victim was driven around in the boot of a car for four hours before he was released and told not to contact family members or the police, the court heard.Surgeons attempted to reattach Mr Dohertys hand to his arm after the attack in Northolt, West London.Three weeks after the incident Mary Connor, the sister-in-law of Francis Doherty, was allegedly called by members of the Connors family telling them to drop the case for £50,000.If they did not accept, they threatened to kill her and her family, the court was told.Connors, of no fixed address, Daniel Connors, of Northolt, Elston, from North West London, and the 17-year-old girl deny conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to kidnap, conspiracy to falsely imprison, and conspiracy to wound with intent.Connors also denies attempted murder and causing wounding with intent to cause grievous bodily harm.The Connors sister Christina, 18, and her boyfriend Aidan Mason, 20, are accused of offering £50,000 in cash  Mr Doherty refused to co-operate with police.Mason, from Tottenham, and Christina Connors, from north-west London, both deny perverting the course of justice.The trial continues.

title: moonpig begs customers to stop uploading pics of their genitals to cards in hilarious tweet
story: The custom cards company had people creasing up with its saucy announcement through its official UK Twitter account this morning.It said: Please stop uploading pics of your genitals to our cards it is against our ts and cs.Moonpigs online photo editor allows customers to put their own snaps on greeting cards, as well as other gts including phone cases, t-shirts and mugs.But it seems theyve had enough of seeing some peoples private sentiments being pasted on their presents.The companys content rules strictly prohibit any material that is pornographic, obscene, indecent or offensive being printed on their personalised cards and goods.Clearly some people didnt read the small print.A Moonpig spokesperson told The Sun Online: We’ll produce anywhere between 100-200k cards a day and at least two or three of those might infringe our terms.We have one guy who’s particularly good at spotting them although a couple occasionally slip through the cracks.We also see a massive rise around Valentines Day, with as many as 20 a day that we have to deny.And yes, the girls are as bad as the boys.Followers of the online card company came out with some hilarious responses to the rude revelation.Rachel Hawkins said: My Dad is very apologetic but hes going through a bad time.No excuse I know.Moonpig was in a forgiving mood and replied As long as hes aware now.Scott Bond asked the company: Do you do pop-up cards? Asking for friend.And even more worrying was @Sharron_Ps response.She said: Sorry. Ill have a word with Gran... again.Moonpig was originally founded in 2000 but was bought by online photo printing company in 2011 for £120million.

title: newlyweds house pink clingfilm return from honeymoon
story: Jenny and Jonathan Minger jetted home from a luxury two week trip in Mexico to discover the unusual surprise.Their four friends spent three hours painstakingly wrapping the home in Stoke with pink tape.Dairy farmer Jonathan uses the tape to wrap hay bales and promote breast cancer awareness.Jenny, 25, told Stoke Sentinel: We were shocked, it was a big surprise. We weren’t expecting it at all.We only moved in three months ago. I was like ‘Oh my goodness!’. They couldn’t have chosen a better colour to wrap it with.Johns bosses James and Dawn Oulton and pals Andrew Ripley and Dan Sale worked overnight to make sure the prank would be ready for the couples  today.The 24-year-old said: I was a bit surprised, but it’s a bit of a laugh.“We got back this morning at about 8am and it took about half an hour to get down with a pen kne.“I had to use my car keys at first though to cut through the plastic around the front door.”Jonathan is now plotting a way to get his revenge on his pals.

title: tattoo addict walking advert brand logos facebook pepsi monster
story: Scott Lincoln, 46, insists he has absolutely ‘no regrets’ after getting his entire body inked with 68 tatts - including 20 logos of his favourite drinks, movies and games.The dad-of-eight from Hobart, Tasmania, Australia, claims to be proud of his vast collection of popular culture tatts, with the retired firefighter revealing they were a way to pay homage to some of his favourite things in le.And his devoted we Elisabete, 43, was so inspired by her husband’s tattoos that she also decided to get the logo of her favourite supermarket Woolworths inked on her hand - hitting the headlines earlier this month for the bizarre stunt.Scott said: “I used to be really afraid of getting tattoos because I thought they would hurt.“But like everyone always says, once you get one you just want more. They’re really addictive.“I have 68 tattoos in total, and lots of them are logos of my favourite drinks, movies, and games.“My we tells me I’m like a walking advertisement. I always laugh about it, we think it’s great.“She recently got a Woolworths tattoo as well to show her devotion to the brand.“I always used to drink a lot of Pepsi, as well as other energy drinks like V, Monster and Mother. So I decided to get their logos inked on my skin.“If any new drinks come out that I really like, I get them tattooed on me.“It’s the same with movies and games. I get the ones I really love inked on me.“A lot of my movie tattoos are from films that my kids love, so they get really happy when they see it on my skin.“That was a big reason why I have so many movie tattoos. I got them for my kids.“I think it will be great to look back on them when I’m older and have all those great memories.”Scott and Elisabete have both insisted that other people’s opinions of their tattoos don’t phase them – and the pair have said that they will continue to get inked in the future.Scott said: “I don’t worry about what other people think. I get these tattoos because I like them, and they look cool.“At the end of the day, it’s my body and other people’s opinions don’t matter.“We’re not the types to take ourselves too seriously. We just really love tattoos and enjoy getting inked.“I’m really proud of them and wouldn’t change a thing.”

title: theresa may justin welby government
story: Justin Welby sided with Britain’s union bosses a fortnight ago to deliver an extraordinary left-wing tirade against the Government - claiming the economy was rigged, the minimum wage too low and calling for major tax hikes.But in a firm rebuttal the Prime Minister – a regular church goer – said she had delivered on her steps of Downing Street pledge to deliver an “economy that works for everyone”.She conceded that “on occasions” she disagreed with the Archbishop.But she signalled he was wrong to attack her economic policies by listing her achievements since taking power – including record employment stats and a new industrial strategy delivering “good jobs in all parts of the UK”.Speaking to reporters on her trip to the UN General Assembly in New York on Wednesday night, she said: “When I stood on the doorstep of No10 when I first became Prime Minister I was clear that there are some changes we need to make to make sure we have a country that works for everyone.“That’s about making sure we have an economy that works for everyone, that’s what we’re doing with the work we’re doing particularly on the industrial strategy, ensuring we are able to see those good jobs being created in all parts of the UK.“I think the employment figures we see in the UK are very important because work is the best route out of poverty.“Having systems that encourage people to work, ensuring those jobs are being created are important.The PM added: “But the Archbisop and I will sometimes disagree on things.”Jeremy Corbyn used his Labour conference speech to praise Mr Welby’s intervention - saying he was right to argue economic justice “needs to be hard-wired into the way the economy works”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: holidaymakers share shocking photos of battered and broken suitcases after manchester airport handlers caught hurling bags onto trailer
story: Footage emerged of a careless worker throwing suitcases so hard they smashed onto the tarmac.He was captured by shocked traveller Elizabeth Evans, after a Ryanair flight landed from Malaga last week.Now passengers have now been posting images of their broken baggage following ious flights this month.It isnt clear  the bags were damaged during their journeys to and from Manchester Airport or  it was careless Swissport workers.Craig Coop, 55, and his we Susan, 34, arrived at Manchester from watching the Grand Prix in Singapore to find their bags crushed.He said: We were appalled to see our suitcases coming down the conveyor crushed. These are £200 bags. It takes some force to break the wheels and crush them like that.The contractor for a flight simulator firm claims his iPad screen was cracked so he lodged a Swissports customer service desk.He said: They said it wasnt damaged enough for them to do anything and wed have to contact Etihad.We were trying to explain how dficult the wheels would make our train journey. They just didnt care.Michelle Knight also shared pictures of her broken bag after travelling to Almeria, Spain, from Manchester Airport.And Hannah Henry, 21, from Stockport, flew back from Palma in Spain on June 26 to find her bag was destroyed.She said: I noticed straight away when it came off the conveyor. There was a big crack down one side.Hannah has now had to fight through Tui to get her bag replaced - and she said she had to settle for a lesser version of the original.A Swissport spokesman said: “We take our baggage handling responsibilities very seriously and we handle all complaints on a case by case basis.”It comes after Elizabeth posted the shocking footage online when she noticed her own case slide off the trailer and onto the floor with the force it is thrown.She can be heard saying thats mine yeah, as her pink suitcase topples to the ground - while the workers colleague looks on.The 28-year-old, from Bury, told the Manchester Evening News: Im very angry and shocked. It was a new case. The case is dented and the protective layer has been torn off it.The Swissport worker can be seen chucking bags onto the trailer without looking, and only stops to scoop up the fallen cases after five had hit the ground.A Manchester Airport spokeswoman said: “We are disappointed to see this unacceptable handling of bags by a Swissport employee and have raised this with them directly.”Meanwhile, a £1,000 guitar case made from the same material as a Boeing 787 was destroyed by easyJet baggage handlers.John Challis posted footage of him picking up the indestructible carbon fibre case in Berlin to discover it had gouges and cracks in it.EasyJet have apologised for the incident and say they are looking into the issue.

title: family visit one thousand wetherspoons ten year pub crawl
story: The Latchfords have spent 10 years touring Britain and Ireland and were first through the door at the chains latest opening in Somerset last week.They ticked off 900 in the first six years but were so prolic they have since had to wait for new ones to open.The only existing bars they havent been to yet are the two beyond security at Heathrows Terminal 5 - which they plan to attend the next time they go on holiday.Their odyssey began with a throwaway promise that mum Sheila, 61, made to son Christy, then 17, which, due to his autism, he took literally and held them to.Sheila, of Kidderminster, said: Our daughter Amy works at the Penny and Black Wetherspoon in Kidderminster and when she started Christy was not yet 18.We wanted to take him in to show her working behind the bar but in those days they had a really strict rule which meant anyone under 18 had to have a meal.We had just eaten so left. I said rather foolishly, or fortunately depending on how you look at it, dont worry, when you are 18 we will go to all of them.When you say something like that to someone with autism it is taken seriously. The minute he turned 18 he was back in the Penny and Black in Kidderminster.We were never intending to do them all, but had promised him and he wouldnt let us forget it.It didnt occur to us it could be doable until I had to go to Scotland to work. They drove me up and we went to ones in Dundee and Edinburgh and it just went from there.The chain currently has around 900 pubs open across the UK but some of the ones the Latchford family have previously visited have since closed.Sheila, husband Keith, 63, and Christy took six years to do the first 900 but in the last four years they have had to wait for new ones to open.The family did all the local area ones first around the Midlands which they could get to in a day and back, before focusing on big cities such as Manchester, Liverpool, Bristol and London whilst also enjoying some sightseeing.They have been to every corner of the UK and to Ireland three times to do all the Wetherspoon pubs in both Northern and Southern Ireland.Sheila, a part-time civil servant, added: It was a lot easier when there were loads to do, we could just fly up to Glasgow and walk around and come straight back.We would often book the night away, next week we are going to the new one in St Pancreas when it opens.We only target openings now and keep a close eye on the website and are part of the Wetherspoon appreciation society group on Facebook.The only ones we have not been to are the ones in Heathrow terminal 5 which are after security. We will have to do that when we plan our next holiday.But as far as we know we have done every other one in the UK and Southern Ireland.The family reached the 1,000 milestone when they were first through the door at the opening of the Palladium Electric in Midsomer Norton, Somerset, last week.The latest one in Midsomer Norton was our 1,000th, Sheila said. They dont serve Champagne anymore but we had a nice bottle of sparkling wine instead.It was a real landmark but unfortunately we were only there for a limited time but had a good look around.Sheila says their orders y from coffees to pints and on around half the 1,000 occasions they have added either a breakfast or evening meal to their visit.She added: We really like them and always make a beeline for them even  they are ones we have been to before.The prices are very reasonable but we also love the surroundings. They refurbish a lot of old buildings and there are lots of converted churches, banks, theatres etc.Probably the old Caley picture house in Edinburgh is our favourite but there are so many really good ones.We also all really like the Cabot Court hotel in Weston-super-Mare which is right on the seafront.Keith, a full time carer for Christy, now 28, said: Everyone tends to say that the historical buildings are the best, and that is true.There are some beautul conversions of old premises and some of the newer pubs in particular are fantastic.It is a great hobby for us together and Christy loves it.Wetherspoon founder and chairman Tim Martin congratulated the family on their achievement.He said: “This is a wonderful achievement by Sheila, Keith and Christy.“They must have travelled tens of thousands of miles over the years to visit each Wetherspoon pub.“We thoroughly appreciate their loyalty and commitment and trust they will continue to visit our pubs for many more years to come.”

title: backlash after cop dresses lgbt bee
story: The officer donned the bizarre outfit along with yellow sunglasses to promote a pro-LGBT Pride march on 22 September.But Greater Manchester Police was blasted for the stunt in Bolton, which also marked “hate crime awareness” week.Mark Acaster said: “I am an adult gay male. I don’t want special treatment. I want a police force run by seasoned officers who enforce the law, and are respected by the people they serve. This is a patronising and embarrassing PR disaster.”Sara Lovett replied: “Here’s a thought... stop with all this PC, virtue signalling nonsense and do your damn job.“In a time of rising crime, lack of police visibility this really isn’t what the public want to see. Badly misjudged the public mood.”Simon Lewis added: “Perhaps instead of being inclusive, here is a radical thought do your F**king jobs. No one cares  you are gay, straight or identy as a shoe. Do your f***ing jobs, or should I say have PRIDE in your work by cleaning up the scum you seem to ignore 24/7. GMP is a joke.”And Ryan Daintree hit out at the stunt, saying: “Cringeworthy! #pride should be getting on those streets and arresting criminals and terrorists!“Not dressing as a big rainbow but  you’re gonna go down that road I hope to see you’re officers dressed as giant poppies for Armistice Day, we shall see.”Earlier this month, GMP Deputy Chief Constable Ian Pilling said a reduction in officer numbers and the “changing nature and complexity” of crime “means that we have to focus our resources where they are needed most’”.He spoke out after the force was criticised as new figures revealed no suspects are identied in three quarters of vehicle thefts reported to GMP. And four in five residential burglary cases are close without identying a suspect, according to the study of Home Office data of the 12 months to March.The survey also found almost half of all shoplting investigations fail to find a suspect.Manchester Mayor Andy Burnham has previously accused the Government of “gambling” with public safety by cutting front-line policing in the city for the eighth year in a row.Last year crime in the region rose by 31 per cent. title: the luminaries bbc eva green book release
story: Here we reveal who is starring on it, when it is on, and who wrote the original.The Luminaries does not yet have a broadcast date - but filming will start in the coming November.The six-part series will be broadcast on BBC2, and will tell the story of Anna Wetherell, who sailed from Britain for a new le.The show is being produced by Working Title and the BBC, and filming is set to take place in New Zealand.It is set on New Zealands South Island during the 1860s gold rush.Brothel madam Lydia Wells will be played by Casino Royale star Eva Green.Anna Wetherell will be played by Bridge of Spies actor Eve Hewson.Lord of The Rings star Marton Csokas will appear as villain Francis Carver.The book was released in August 2013.It went on to claim the Man Booker prize that year, making author Eleanor Catton the awards youngest-ever recipient.The book was adapted for TV with Claire McCarthy, who worked on Ophelia.

title: chancellor announces early budget
story: The Treasury announced the date yesterday - just days after denying to The Sun that it would be brought forward to avoid a Parliamentary log jam.It means critical decisions over tax and spending will be presented to MPs before any Brexit deal is agreed with Brussels.Ardent Eurosceptics have claimed some in their ranks could vote down parts of the Budget in protest at any further concessions to the EU. It marks the first time a Budget or Autumn Statement has been held on Monday since the height of the credit crisis ten years ago.In November 2008, then Chancellor Alistair Darling said Labour announced a borrowing binge to try and kick-start the economy and lt it out of recession.Taking to Twitter yesterday, Philip Hammond said: “I’ll set out how our balanced approach is getting debt falling while supporting our vital public services, and how we are building a stronger, more prosperous economy.”Government insiders yesterday admitted the earlier date meant “big economic decisions” were unlikely. But the Chancellor is under pressure to relieve the strain on strivers while finding money for the NHS and the police.Theresa May earlier this month admitted tax hikes were inevitably going to be required to help pay for a £20 billion NHS windfall.But experts last week said borrowing had come down at such a rate no new hikes may be needed this year.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eu to intesify no deal preperation
story: Member States are intensying contingency measures amid suspicions Jeremy Corbyn will vote down the withdrawal agreement to try and force an election.They believe an alliance of Labour MPs and Tory eurosceptics could oppose the final deal in parliament, leading to Britain crashing out of the club. The development came as as the PMs beleagured Chequers plan was dealt another hefty blow yesterday as a France launched a fresh attack on it.The new No Deal plans are contained in a leaked diplomatic note, seen by The Sun, issued to EU ambassadors ahead of a meeting in Brussels yesterday.It says: Preparedness has to intensy in the months ahead at national as well as at EU level, as uncertainty remains about the outcome of the negotiations and the ratication of a possible deal. Shadow Brexit secretary Keir Starmer said on Tuesday that his party is likely to vote down any pact Mrs May secures with Brussels.And Mr Corbyn is set to meet EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier this afternoon after renaming a square in Brussels after murdered MP Jo Cox.An EU official told The Sun: From our side the political risks are relatively limited. The likelihood that  we make a deal that this goes through the Parliament that this is accepted by the Member States, is nearly guaranteed.You cant say that on the UK side. Theres a political risk factor because I dont think Labour will ever, ever help May.We will watch the UK domestic scene in the coming weeks with even bigger interest than we already do.Meanwhile, EU diplomats told The Sun countries are also hardening their stance on no deal to try and scare off Jacob Rees-Moggs ERG. Capitals have formed a common position to rebuff UK pleas for a series of mini-deals in the event of a no deal Brexit.  British negotiators aim to strike pacts with inidual member states and even regions covering areas like aviation and food and medicine. Instead, capitals will stress a no deal scenario would involve an immediate switch to WTO trading terms and Brits requiring visas to visit the continent.An EU diplomat told The Sun: No deal means no deal, and that includes no inidual deals. Well only get the consent of the House of Commons  the price of no deal is really high.MPs must know they have to agree to the deal so as not to have a catastrophic situation. The price must be too high in order not to say no. They stressed the tough stance is a unied EU position, adding: We will not talk to the Brits bilaterally about a deal on a no deal.Another diplomat said capitals were particularly spooked when Mrs May was forced to back down and accept ERG amendments to her Customs Bill in July. They said the development had a knock on effect on the talks and spurred member states into hardening their resolve not to give ground.It is understood EU countries could still take unilateral action in the event of no deal, such as deciding to let planes from the UK still land. But EU sources said such a scenario would be acrimonious and that to agree contingency deals in advance would undermine their own negotiating position.Paris finance minister Bruno Le Maire said the PM had been brave to draw up the blueprint but that it wont wash with EU capitals. His remarks were echoed by Danuta Hubner, who sits on the EU Parliaments Brexit steering group and urged Mrs May to ditch the proposal.Mr Le Maire said: “I’m sorry to say it so callously, there is something more important for us than the future of the UK and that’s the future of the EU. Any decision that would give European citizens the feeling you can exit the EU and keep all the advantages would be suicidal.Ms Hubner added: Its frustrating to us that the UK has left the same unworkable arguments on the table for so long without changing them at all. It has become clear that the remaining issues cannot be resolved by civil servants and officials – political engagement from the UK is needed.The Polish MEP, who chairs the Parliaments constitutional affairs committee, added the blocs treaties prohibit the PMs preferred customs plan .She said: The FCA is an innovation that has no precedent worldwide, has never been tested, and is based on a non-existent technology.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: And some of them chanting the slogan “from the river to the sea” favoured by Hamas and the PLO, who demand the liquidation of Israel.Lovely people.That will have put to rest any worries the British Jewish community might have, no? And they STILL claim they’re not anti-Semitic.Some dizzy bint then got up and demanded a general strike. Right now! Everyone out! Why? To “bring down” the hated Tories. And unable to find work.Dirt cheap childcare for everyone, even the rich. Paid for, then, by who?Nationalisation of the water and power companies and the railways. Well, I’ve got no objection to that. But you still have to keep asking yourself — where is the money coming from?And on Brexit? Scarcely a word. The most important issue facing the country right now and Labour had next to nothing to say about it.But we know they’re planning to support a second referendum on the issue. Selling down the river the millions of Labour voters who thought we were best out of the European Union.At first, Labour — with great principle — stuck to the decision of the referendum.Not now they see a chance of power, the prospect of hoovering up all those votes from Remainers who think we got it wrong two years ago. There is great inequality in our country. Low wages and poor standards of living in many parts. We need a Labour Party that will support the working class ­— and lay the bloody wind turbines and their horrible Palestinian flags to one side.Not a chance.They will enter the next election as a Marxist fringe, frantically virtue-signalling to all and sundry.The Labour Party I once loved is dead.DAME JUDI DENCH has been sticking up for the “disgraced” actor, Kevin Spacey.She described him as a friend and said it was ridiculous to cut him out of films.That was brave of her. He complained that despite all the money he’d paid, the kidleft with useless grades.There’s a lesson for you in there, some- where, Gary,  you can work out what it is.She doesn’t like the way British news- papers are reporting our Brexit negotiations. title: phone deals public over paying
story: Ofcom is concerned that 1.5 million on bundled deals continue to pay the original price after the minimum contract period ends.Providers do not tell them they have paid off the handset, and need to pay only for calls, texts and data.Ofcom yesterday said it was “unacceptable” that providers were not open about the costs of each part of the package.It is now consulting on ­making firms break down the cost of each.It will also look at what extra information should be given to customers.Providers could be forced to automatically move customers to a cheaper SIM-only plan once they reach the minimum term of any contract which includes a handset.Or they may have to reduce the monthly cost to reflect that the handset element has been paid off.The charity said EE, Three and Vodafone routinely continued to charge customers for handsets after they had paid them off in full. Gillian Guy, of Citizens Advice, said: “This move could make a real dference.“While greater transparency around pricing would be a step in the right direction, what ­people really want is not to be charged for products they already own.”Ofcom is seeking comments on the proposals by November 7.GOT a story? title: homework works parents help
story: He thinks he is stupid and that little Amy is clever because she knows all the answers.What he doesn’t realise is that Amy does her homework with her family every night.American comedian Rob Delaney ignited a lively debate when he tweeted: “Why do they give seven-year-olds so much homework in the UK and how do I stop this?I want my kid frolicking and drawing and playing football.”Fellow celebrities Gary Lineker and Jason Manford agreed.Piers Morgan disagreed, calling the arguments “lazy parenting”.I have to disagree too with Mr Delaney and his supporters.Homework is essential for a child’s education because revisiting the day’s learning is what helps to make it stick.So Catastrophe star Rob and Gary Lineker are wrong in attacking compulsory home-work in primary schools.Sure, you’ll get the odd exceptionally bright pupil who will excel just through what she learns at school, despite not having that support at home.But this is very rare.Teaching is not just the teacher’s job.It takes a village to raise a child.Children learn all the time and the environment surrounding them determines how much they learn.Genes play a part in how clever a child is, but how hard they work also matters.Work hard and you’ll learn lots.Work less and you’ll learn less.Don’t make the mistake of thinking homework is for a child to do on their own.When parents use homework to bond and learn together with their child, the child understands that Mum and Dad value learning.And because a child wants to please their parents, the child’s interest in their home-work will grow, year on year.These children can see the benefit of homework and will enjoy doing it because it makes them feel better about themselves.Everyone loves to feel successful.Ten years ago, author Malcolm Gladwell introduced the idea that it takes 10,000 hours of practice to become an expert in something.We get better at what we practise, whether it’s football or maths.Our brains have a working memory and a long-term memory.If your times tables are stored in your long-term memory, you will quickly be able to calculate what it will cost to buy 12 apples instead of two.If that knowledge isn’t there, you’ll have to resort to counting on your fingers.The more knowledge stored in long-term memory, the better equipped you’ll be to think imaginatively and solve complex problems.Homework revisits what you learn at school to cement it into your long-term memory.I do agree that some home-work is pointless.Silly craft projects that involve gluing things together, which the parent will inevitably end up doing, hold no value for me.I also understand why some parents don’t like homework — they feel that it’s a battle.Parenting is hard.I get that.But we need to stop thinking of homework as a chore that the child is sent off to do, cutting into the parent’s precious time with them.It shouldn’t be the case on Sunday night that Mum says: “Oh God, it’s homework time — let’s get it over with.”Instead, learning should be part of daily le, and an enriching time for both the parent and the child.Reading with your child for 20 minutes should not be a chore.Asking them to count peas on their plate should not be hard work.While you’re out in the street, talk to them about the world around them.This is the sort of homework that is often set for very young children and it can be done without making it feel like a formal lesson.It doesn’t need to be half an hour sitting at a desk.It can just be ten minutes of enjoyable time together.Homework can be written down but can also be spoken or done online, leaving little marking for the teacher.Secondary-school homework can help you learn with your child.You can learn some French again or be reminded of the beauty of Shakespeare!How wonderful is that?By scaffolding the support at home, you can gradually wean them off it, just like taking off bike stabilisers.Eventually, they learn to work independently, so that when they get to GCSEs, they will be in the habit of doing their homework each night.If you don’t get them into the homework habit from an early age, you risk having a battle with a stroppy teen as they approach their exams.And no parent wants that.Those who are against homework will argue that their children have no time for other hobbies.This is nonsense.Children generally finish school at 3.15pm, and younger ones tend to go to bed at about 8pm.That’s nearly five hours of free time.Are they really spending it playing hockey or going to Brownies?I doubt it.Half an hour of homework in five hours of spare time is a drop in the ocean, leaving lots of time for other things.The real worry for parents should be how much time children are spending on social media — something that is so very dangerous and takes up hours of their time, unlike homework.Katharine Birbalsingh is head of Michaela Community School, North London, and has been dubbed the country’s “strictest head teacher”.She introduced an ultra-disciplined approach to learning called Tiger Teaching.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. It shows how quickly property prices have outstripped wage growth.In Birmingham, Nottingham and Leicester buyers now need 23 per cent more.In pricey Cambridge the earnings needed have fallen by three per cent but still stand at £74,000.The figures assumed buyers would take out a repayment mortgage over 30 years, would not ­borrow more than four times their salary and would spend up to 30 per cent of gross income on mortgage costs.Hometrack also used average mortgage interest rates and the size of deposits put down by first-time buyers.Richard Donnell of Hometrack said: “Cities like London and Cambridge require the highest incomes to buy a home and as a result they are registering flat, to falling, prices.“Meanwhile, cities like Bristol and Bournemouth are starting to register slower growth as affordability pressures increase.“Higher prices and a further drt upwards in mortgage rates means that these affordability pressures will continue to steadily build.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn labour would back sensible brexit deal
story: A senior Labour source insisted the party were sticking to their six tests for a Brexit deal, but said Mr Corbyn was "reaching out to create political space" for the PM to agree a Brexit deal.It comes after a conference dominated by debate on Labour's "constructive ambiguity" on Brexit, with the party not ruling out support for a second referendum but also pledging to respect the 2016 Leave vote.In an hour-long speech to a packed hall, Mr Corbyn pledged a "green jobs revolution" and an expansion of free childcare.He also denounced "greed-is-good capitalism", which he said was holding the UK economy back."People in this country know - they showed that in June last year [at the general election] - that the old way of running things isn't working anymore," he said. "That's why Labour is offering a radical plan to rebuild and transform Britain."He accused the "political and corporate establishment" of propping up the financial system which caused millions of people misery in the wake of the 2008 financial crash.Seeking to sketch out details of how Labour would try to change what he sees as a broken system, Mr Corbyn pledged to::: Work with industry and unions to create 400,000 "green jobs" by 2030, with investment focused on offshore and onshore wind, solar energy and home energy efficiency:: Set an ambitious target to reduce net carbon emissions by 60% by 2030 and to zero by 2050:: An extension of free childcare:: Give workers seats on company boards and set up employee shareholding funds:: End what he called the "racket" of privatisation and outsourcing:: Bring in a tax on second homes to fund an ambitious house-building programme:: Oversee a foreign policy with "progressive values and international solidarity" at its heart, with no more "reckless wars, like Iraq or Libya":: Recognise a Palestinian state upon entering Downing Street"We can no longer tolerate a set-up where the real economy, in which millions work, is just a sort of sideshow for the City of London and for banks fixated on piling up profits around the world," he told the conference.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2"

title: labour conference jeremy corbyn spoke as if a general election is months away
story: Children Of The Revolution, a 1972 hit for T. Rex - no jokes about the Labour leader being an old dinosaur, please! - is an apt description of many of the delegates attending this conference: young, left-wing and clamouring for a socialist revolution under Mr Corbyn.And to listen to Mr Corbyn - and his closest ally John McDonnell earlier this week - you'd think Labour's red revolution was just round the corner and a general election was imminent.Their speeches sounded like those of an opposition leader and shadow chancellor when it's known that an election is only months away. Mr Corbyn received no fewer than 10 standing ovations during and at the end of his speech.But the biggest was when he said Labour would press for a general election and called on Theresa May and the Tories to make way for Labour.Yet in fringe meetings during the week, most Labour backbenchers who spoke injected a dose of realism and were highly sceptical about the likelihood of an early election, predicting - rightly, surely - that the Tories are not going to risk giving up power by going to the polls.The other really big standing ovation Mr Corbyn won was when he said Labour would "recognise a Palestinian state as soon as we take office".Again, as there was during the foreign affairs debate 24 hours earlier, there was waving of Palestinian flags by delegates in the hall. Mr Corbyn had a good passage in his speech on antisemitism, admitting this summer's row had "caused immense hurt and anxiety in the Jewish community and great dismay in the Labour Party".But critics will say his reassuring words to the Jewish community - "We are your ally" - should have been said months ago.Having said that, this was probably Mr Corbyn's best speech as Labour leader - less rambling than some and delivered in a conversational tone with contrasts in pitch and delivery that suggested he'd had some coaching.His Brexit passage was deftly executed too, especially his offer to "reach out to the prime minister" and back the Tories  they get a good deal but to vote against an agreement with the EU  they don't.And one of the smartest lines in Mr Corbyn's hour-long speech was when he attacked Tory eurosceptics like Jacob Rees-Mogg, who was loudly booed by Labour delegates in true pantomime villain style."The Tory Brexiteers unite the politics of the 1950s with the economics of the 19th century, daydreaming about a Britannia that both rules the waves and waives the rules," he said. Nice line.Brexit has been a muddle and a struggle for Mr Corbyn and the Labour leadership this week. First a group of party fixers spent six hours, meeting long into the night to agree on the wording of the motion to be debated and voted on by the conference.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2"
