title: 13 explosive moments jeremy corbyns
story: News13 explosive moments from Jeremy Corbyn's Labour Party Conference speech as he declares: 'We are ready'The Labour leader set out a radical plan to rebuild Britain - slamming corporate greed, vowing to kill Theresa May's Brexit plan "as it stands" and declaring his party "the new mainstream"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporterDan BloomOnline Political Editor14:48, 26 SEP 2018Updated23:16, 26 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/politics/video/watch-jeremy-corbyn-makes-speech-13313074,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJeremy Corbyn set out his radical plan to rebuild Britain today in a stomping speech to the 2018 Labour Party Conference. He used his annual address to his admirers in Liverpool to outline his pitch for a Labour government, telling thousands of party faithful: “Labour is ready.” In an hour-long speech that paused for applause 104 times, he promised a ‘green jobs revolution’, a tax on second homes, and free childcare for all. In a touching tribute in Spanish to his publicity-shy we Laura Alez, he said: You are my force and my support. Thank you Laurita. He addressed the anti-Semitism row which has dogged the party for what he admitted was a “tough” summer.  Boris Johnson, Theresa May - and of course the media - felt the sharp end of Corbyn’s tongue There were even a few pretty good jokes. And, of course, Brexit came up - with the leader vowing as it stands to kill off Theresa May's plan for leaving the EU. Here’s the most explosive moments of Jeremy Corbyn’s keynote speech to Labour Party Conference.  Corbyn was given a y standing ovation as he addressed the party’s anti-Semitism row - telling the Jewish community, “We are your ally”. The Labour leader admitted this Summer had been “tough” but he pleaded with people to “draw a line” under the saga. His carefully-worded statement said it was “the row over antisemitism” that “caused immense hurt and anxiety in the Jewish community and great dismay in the Labour Party”, rather than anti-Semitism itself. And he accused political opponents who attacked Labour over the row of hypocrisy. He said: “We won’t accept it when we’re attacked by Tory hypocrites who accuse us of antisemitism one day, then endorse Viktor Orban’s hard right government the next. But he also promised to fight anti-Semitism “with every breath I possess.” He added: “I say this to all in the Jewish community: This party, this movement, will always be implacable campaigners against antisemitism and racism in all its forms. We are your ally.” 2. He declared he'd kill off May's Brexit plan - but gave her a big olive branch  Mr Corbyn made it clear that as it stands, Labour will vote against Theresa May's Brexit plan - which would spell a disastrous defeat for the PM in Parliament. The way ahead is clear,” he declared, despite days of confusion and argument about whether Labour could back a second vote - with the option of Remain. “As it stands, Labour will vote against the Chequers plan or whatever is left of it and oppose leaving the EU with no deal. But he also offered an olive branch to the PM. He said: Deliver a deal that includes acustoms union, no hard border in Ireland, protect jobs, rights at work, environmental and consumer standards, we’ll support that sensible deal.” Delegates applauded as he added: “If you can’t negotiate that, make way for a party that can.” This is an interesting offer. Mr Corbyn did not mention Labour's 'six tests' for the deal to pass - suggesting, perhaps, he could be rolling the pitch for watering them down. This is confirmed, though. And there's something pretty important to note - Theresa May has repeatedly refused to enter a customs union.  Delegates whooped and applauded as Corbyn attacked capitalism - after confirming Labour would institute a mass sacking of water firm bosses and force companies to fill a third of their boards with workers. He said: Ten years ago this month, the whole edice of greed-is-good deregulated financial capitalism, lauded for a generation as the only way to run a modern economy, came crashing to earth with devastating consequences. But instead of making essential changes to a broken economic system, the political and corporate establishment strained every sinew to bail out and prop up the system that led to the crash in the first place. The price of that has not just been stagnation, wages falling for the longest period in recorded history, and almost a decade of deeply damaging cuts to public services.  The conference hall gave its biggest standing ovation of the day after Corbyn promised to recognise the Palestinian state as soon as we take office. Palestinian flags were waved in the hall as delegates cheered. All week, hundreds of delegates have been wearing Palestine lanyards to carry their conference passes. Slamming the “ongoing denial of justice and rights”, Mr Corbyn declared: “Our Party is united in condemning the shooting of hundreds of unarmed demonstrators in Gaza by Israeli forces and the passing of Israel’s discriminatory Nation-State Law. “The continuing occupation, the expansion of illegal settlements and the imprisonment of Palestinian children are an outrage. We support a two-state solution to the conflict with a secure Israel and a viable and secure Palestinian state.” Repeating Labour’s existing policy, Corbyn says: “We will recognise a Palestinian state as soon as we take office.” 5. He acknowledged evidence “clearly” points to Russia being behind the Salisbury attack  Corbyn said the evidence around the Salisbury Novichok poisoning “now points clearly to the Russian state”. It was the Labour leader's strongest statement yet on the attack, and a big step after he faced months of criticism for questioning the evidence he was provided by the government. He said: “We are entering a new fast-changing and more dangerous world including the reckless attacks in Salisbury - which the evidence painstakingly assembled by the police now points clearly to the Russian state.”  Mr Corbyn blasted the Tories for receiving a hand-signed letter of thanks from Hungarian far-right leader Viktor Orban for their “solidarity”, voting not to sanction him in the European Parliament. Then Mr Corbyn turned his fire on Boris Johnson, who said burqa-wearing women look like letterboxes. He said: “Our Party will never stay silent in the face of growing Islamophobia, whether from the far right on the streets, or the former Foreign Secretary’s disgraceful dog-whistle jibes at Muslim women. Labour will work to bring communities together. It is only through the unity of all our people that we can deliver social justice for anyone.” 7. He told an EXCELLENT joke at Jacob Rees-Mogg's expense - complete with pantomime booing  Mr Corbyn said the Tory government are bringing in the lowest corporation tax of any comparable country. Conference booed. “And then there’s Jacob Rees-Mogg!” He said. This time conference REALLY booed. And then he told the best joke of conference season so far, saying Tory Brexiteers are daydreaming about a Britannia that both rules the waves and waives the rules.” He also took aim at Liam Fox, who he said was, “itching to scrap workers’ rights and privatise the NHS ... with a side order of chlorinated chicken.” 8. He announced Labour would dramatically increase the amount of free childcare  Unlimited free childcare will be available for the poorest families under a Labour government, Jeremy Corbyn confirmed. The leader promised a major expansion of the policy to help parents of children aged two to four. Labour already promised last year to offer 30 hours per week of free childcare for all children aged two to four - not just those who work. Despite this being an old policy, Corbyn said “today I can announce” it. The new bit is that Labour will “phase in” a new, additional system that will allow parents to claim extra subsidised hours on top of 30 per week. Labour sources said the extra hours would be available to all parents of kids aged two to four. They would be free for households earning less than &pound16,000, and &pound4 an hour for those earning over &pound66,000, with a sliding scale of fees in between.  Sources said there would be no limit to the number of extra hours a family could claim - effectively making the free hours offer limitless for the poorest households. Labour said Mr Corbyn will also increase funding for nurseries that say they have struggled to afford the Tories' free childcare scheme. Parents would get a new online portal to manage their account after complaints about the existing system. Over two terms - which could be as late as 2032 - childcare workers would be required to have a 'level 3' qualication  or be working towards one. And pay for all childcare workers would be hiked from a current minimum of &pound7.20 an hour to at least &pound10.Decent early years education is now at risk of becoming a privilege, Jeremy Corbyn said.  Mr Corbyn used his speech to highlight Shadow Housing Minister John Healey's plan to tax holiday homes. The party estimates up to 174,000 homes would be slapped with the new levy, which is equivalent to double the current rate of council tax on each home - around &pound3,000 a year. It could raise more than &pound500million a year, Labour claimed, and would not apply to rental properties or static caravans. Mr Corbyn said: Think of it as a solidarity fund for those with two homes to help those without any home at all. He went on: Labour will embark on the biggest home building programme in half a century. 10. He invited a Tory peer to cross the floor and join “the new political mainstream  Mr Corbyn said: “Labour speaks for the new majority, why last year we won the biggest increase in the Labour vote since 1945, and why Labour’s ideas have caught “the mood of our time”. “And conference, it isn’t me saying that – it’s a former Conservative Treasury minister, Lord O’Neill. Former Goldman Sachs chief economist Lord O'Neill quit the Northern Powerhouse and Tory whip in 2016, later slamming Conservative splits. “I’ve never sought to capture the mood of a Tory minister before, but let me say to his Lordship: you’re welcome, come and join us in the new political mainstream.” 11. He ranted at the media for 'spreading lies' and 'smearing the powerless'  In what has become an annual staple of Corbyn's conference speech, he had a vicious pop at the mainstream media, accusing them of a “propaganda of privilege”. “It turns out that the billionaires who own the bulk of the British press don’t like us one little bit,” he said. “Now it could be because we’re going to clamp down on tax dodging. Or it may be because we don’t fawn over them at white tie dinners and cocktail parties. “Or it could even be because Tom Watson has been campaigning for the second part of the Leveson media inquiry to be set up.” He said freedom of the press must be protected, but adds: “A free press has far too often meant the freedom to spread lies and half-truths, and to smear the powerless, not take on the powerful.” And in a Trump-esque twist, he encouraged supporters to use social media to challenge the media. He said: You challenge their propaganda of privilege by using the mass media of the 21st century: social media. But he urged followers to be nice. He added: We need to foster a much greater culture of tolerance. An end to abuse, online and in person. We must learn to listen a bit more, and shout a lot less. To focus on what unites us. 12. He unveiled his 'green jobs revolution'  Mr Corbyn revealed details of his 'green jobs revolution'. The party has committed to reducing Britain's emissions by 60% by 2030, and eliminating them altogether by 2050. In the process, the party leader claimed Labour would create 400,000 jobs - doubling the number of onshore wind turbines, septupling the number onshore and reversing Tory solar subsidy cuts. He said: I know that sounds ambitious. It is ambitious and will be delivered with the most far-reaching programme of investment and transformation in decades.  In the text of the speech, he was supposed to say at the very end: Our task is to build that Britain and together we can. But he got carried away and said the eminently less quotable: “Our task is to build to Britain, build a Britain together, build a Britain for that security together, and we can!” BONUS: Here is Shadow International Trade Secretary Barry Gardiner whistling the Red Flag. Yes really

title: jeremy corbyn met deafening applause
story: NewsJeremy Corbyn met with deafening applause as he outlines plans to lead Britain out of Tory austerityThe Labour leader earned standing ovations at the Labour conference in Liverpool as spoke of reversing cuts and rescuing "forgotten communities"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAndrew GregoryPolitical Editor20:33, 26 SEP 2018Updated23:00, 26 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/politics/video/watch-jeremy-corbyn-makes-speech-13313074,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJeremy Corbyn was given a deafening round of applause as he set out his radical plans to &shytransform Britain yesterday. Vowing to reverse the cruel years of Tory austerity, the Labour leader said he will rescue our “left-behind areas” and “forgotten communities”. Mr Corbyn insisted he was ready to enter No 10 and challenged ailing Theresa May to call another snap election – telling her his party is “united and ready to win”. And he sought to outfox the Prime Minister on Brexit by offering a proposal for a deal that keeps us in a customs union – silencing critics who claim he is trying to thwart our split from the EU. Mr Corbyn stepped took the stage in Liverpool as delegates – including we Laura Alez – waved their arms and Jeremy Corbyn scarves in the air to You’ll Never Walk Alone. He received a standing ovation as he declared his movement was now the “political mainstream”, adding: “We represent the new common sense of our time. And we are ready to deliver on it. We must speak for the people to whom Theresa May promised so much but has delivered so little.” Promising to give power back to the people, he pledged Labour would heal the rts in the nation, saying: “Where the Tories have ided and ruled, we will unite and govern.” He was repeatedly interrupted by chants of “Oh, Jeremy Corbyn” as he spoke of an “alternative to the &shypolitics of austerity, of social ision and of international conflict”.  And he was applauded as he promised to end the public sector pay cap, close the gender pay gap, nationalise the rail, mail, energy and water sectors, boost house-building, save the NHS and invest in a green economy. Stressing Labour’s new sense of unity, he slammed the PM’s botched Brexit negotiations and mocked Mrs May over Tory infighting on the issue. But he warned his own party faithful they must “listen a bit more and shout a lot less” – and strive to create “a greater culture of tolerance” following bitter rows over anti-Semitism and moderate MPs being threatened with deselection.  Mr Corbyn told the hall: “If we are to get the chance to put those values into practice in government, we are going to need unity to do it. “Our movement has achieved nothing when ided against ourselves. Real unity is based on the freedom to disagree and debate, and then come together around democratic decisions, as we have done this week.” Slamming fat-cats and the banks, he warned: “We can no longer tolerate a set-up where the real economy, in which millions work, is a sideshow for the City of London and banks fixated on piling up profits. We need to explore new forms of ownership and public enterprise.”

title: jeremy corbyns economic medicine looks
story: NewsopinionJeremy Corbyn's economic medicine looks increasingly attractiveThe Labour leader promised to transform a country still reeling from the financial crash. And his plans are chiming with the public moodShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics13:52, 26 SEP 2018NewsopinionJeremy Corbyn reached out to Brexit voters in his speech "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJeremy Corbyn today gave a speech that has been a decade in the making. This was an address to a country which is still suffering ten years after the financial crash. His plans are bold but his pitch was simple: only Labour has the policies which will mend the damage caused by the banking crisis and the subsequent Tory austerity. Labour, he declared, is now the new majority whose ideas have caught the mood of the time. Much of the speech was directed to those areas which voted Leave in the Brexit referendum.  Corbyn made clear he understood their motives and stood ready to help them rebuild their communities. “There will be no more left behind areas,” he said. Yet this speech was an acknowledgement that his party must do more to persuade voters it was fit to govern. First, there was an appeal to the Labour rank and file to show more unity. Divided and hate-filled parties will not win elections. Secondly, he looked to reassure people that while his agenda was radical it was also common sense. Like a kindly doctor speaking to a patient before an operation, he tried to convince them the procedure may be pioneering but was in their best interests.

title: crooks conned people out 145m
story: NewsCrooks conned people out of £145m already this year - here's how to keep your cash safeFrom convincing texts to promoting "last chance" bargain deals - here are the scams to be aware ofShare&nbspByTricia Phillips22:15, 26 SEP 2018NewsSafe wrapped in chains and padlocks "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Financial fraudsters are out in force and coming up with sophisticated scams to take your money.  Some &pound145million was stolen in the first six months of this year by crooks who persuaded people to transfer cash into dodgy accounts. But just &pound31million of that was refunded to victims, leaving countless people with shattered lives. That’s why it’s vital we all do everything we can to protect our hard-earned cash from thieves. Here’s how you can help stop the scammers...  Con tricks The reason so many people get caught out is that fraudsters keep changing methods, with believable scams that can be dficult to spot. They try to catch people out with cold calls, emails and texts, pretending to be from banks, building societies, credit card firms and the taxman, and they send out official-looking correspondence complete with logos. They set up bogus websites selling everything from holidays to cars and fake investments. People are lured in via social media with too-good-to-miss deals on products such as mobiles and computers. They also cash in on data breaches at high-profile firms by impersonating officials just after a hack has taken place to try and catch customers off guard. However convincing someone sounds, it’s best to be cautious and always double check before transferring money anywhere. Telephone calls Hang up on cold calls immediately. Don’t rely on caller ID as thieves can spoof phone numbers to look like they are calling from a trusted person. If you think your bank is trying to contact you, or you want to check something, use the number on your bank card or on the bank’s official website. Use a dferent phone to the one the cold call came in on. Crooks often stay on the line after people hang up and then pretend to be the bank or organisation you are trying to call. A call isn’t fully disconnected until the caller puts the phone down.  Emails Be wary and never click on links in emails. Double-check the sender’s address matches the genuine website address by rolling your mouse pointer over the sender’s name to reveal its true identity. Other warning signs are errors in spelling and grammar, and  they don’t contain your proper name, ie they are addressed to Dear customer. And always be cautious of vague details like a PO Box address or mobile-only phone number. Texts Don’t believe a text is always from a genuine organisation. Rogues have found a way to send texts that appear in the same chain of messages as those from your bank or building society. These often contain links that take you to a fake website to get you to disclose personal and financial information. Or they give out bogus phone numbers. Always type in official website addresses from scratch and only call firms on numbers you know are genuine.  Remote Do not allow someone remote access to your computer after a cold call. Don’t log on to banking  someone is remotely connected to your computer. And never do online banking or carry out financial transactions over free wi connections – such as on trains or in cafes. Transfers One key way fraudsters lure people into transferring cash is by posing as someone from a bank or an official body such as the police. They explain cash needs to be moved for safety reasons. Banks or the police will never get you to transfer money to a new account because of suspected fraud. Need for speed Don’t be rushed into anything. A genuine organisation will not mind  you check the person is who they say they are. Limited-time offers that pressure you into taking action should set alarm bells ringing. Stop, think and double-check. While it might take a little longer to make transactions and to log into accounts, always opt for two-step verication when you can. That means you get a text message when you try to log in from somewhere new. And that will prevent fraudsters getting into your accounts without having access to your mobile phone too. Details Never give out personal information, account details or security information such as passwords or PINs. Your bank or organisation such as the police or HMRC will never ask for these.

title: family visit 1000 wetherspoons pubs
story: NewsFamily visit 1,000 Wetherspoons pubs after making promise to son a decade agoThe family has been on a ten-year tour of the pubs in the UK and IrelandShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMartin Fricker19:16, 26 SEP 2018NewsThe family pictured together at the Palladium Electric Wetherspoons in Midsomer Norton, Somerset "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A family has visited all 1,000 Wetherspoons pubs after making a promise to their son a decade ago.   Sheila and Keith Latchford told their autistic son Christy they would take him to every one of the pubs in the country.  Christy, then 17, kept them to their promise - sparking a ten year tour of the UK and Ireland’s drinking holes. They ticked off 900 Wetherspoons in the first six years but were so prolic they had to wait for new ones to open.  The family, from Kidderminster, Worcestershire, were first through the door at the chain's latest opening in Somerset last week. The only existing bars they have not been to yet are the two beyond security at Heathrow's Terminal 5. Recalling the promise, Sheila, 61, said: “Our daughter Amy works at the Penny and Black Wetherspoon in Kidderminster. “When she started Christy was not yet 18.  “We wanted to take him in to show her working behind the bar but in those days they had a really strict rule which meant anyone under 18 had to have a meal. We had just eaten so left. “I said rather foolishly, or fortunately depending on how you look at it, ‘don’t worry, when you are 18 we will go to all of them.’ “When you say something like that to someone with autism it is taken seriously. “The minute he turned 18 he was back in the Penny and Black. “We were never intending to do them all, but had promised him and he wouldn't let us forget it.”  She said The Caley Picture House in Edinburgh is their favourite, followed by The Cabot Court hotel in Weston-super-Mare. Keith, a full time carer for Christy, now 28, said: “Everyone tends to say that the historical buildings are the best, and that is true. “There are some beautul conversions of old premises and some of the newer pubs in particular are fantastic. “It is a great hobby for us together and Christy loves it.”

story: NewsHappiest places in the UK revealed - how happy are people in your area?The Office for National Statistics survey data, compiled between April 2017 and March 2018, show a new area is top of the happiness chartsShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByClaire MillerCarlos Novoa01:07, 27 SEP 2018NewsPeople in Farnborough, in Britain's happiest area Rushmoor, dancing for joy "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIf you want to find the happiest people in the UK, head for Hampshire. Rushmoor in Hampshire is the place where people gave the highest score to the question, how happy were you yesterday, according to an official Government survey. Respondents rated their average happiness as 8.4 out of 10 in 2017/18, up from 7.8 in 2016/17, meaning the area overtakes Craven in North Yorkshire, which was the happiest place in 2016/17, as the happiest place in the UK. Across the UK, average ratings across the four measures of personal well-being were: 7.7 out of 10 for le satisfaction, 7.9 out of 10 for feeling that what you do in le is worthwhile, 7.5 out of 10 for happiness yesterday and 2.9 out of 10 for anxiety yesterday. The Office for National Statistics survey data, compiled between April 2017 and March 2018 and broken down by local authority, shows average ratings for wellbeing across the UK have not changed overall. So how does your area compare?   The local authority area with the lowest ratings for happiness was Fenland in Cambridgeshire, with 6.7 out of 10. People in Rushmoor also have the highest le satisfaction, rating it as 8.6 out of 10, while people in Broxtowe in Nottinghamshire have the lowest, 7.1 out of 10. For feeling le is worthwhile, again people in Rushmoor gave the highest rating at 8.7 out of 10, while the lowest was in Bromley at 7.4. People in Broxbourne in Hertfordshire felt the most anxious, scoring levels the previous day at 3.9 out of 10, while those in Lisburn and Castlereagh in Northern Ireland were the least anxious, just 1.9 out of 10. Average ratings of feeling the things done in le are worthwhile increased in Scotland this was driven by a higher percentage of people reporting very high levels for this measure. Compared with the UK, a larger percentage of people in Wales reported low levels of worthwhile and happiness. Interestingly, a larger proportion of people in Wales reported both low levels of le satisfaction but also very high levels of le satisfaction, suggesting greater disparity in le satisfaction in Wales compared with the UK overall.

title: meghan markle kate middleton can
story: NewsMeghan Markle and Kate Middleton CAN be arrested  they break the law - but there are some royal loopholesEver wondered what would happen  a member of the royal family committed a major crime?Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer14:13, 26 SEP 2018NewsWhat would happen  they committed a crime? "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email To quote The Princess Bride, it's inconceivable to think of a member of the royal family breaking the law.   The closest we can picture any of them coming to committing a crime is Prince Harry recently swiping some extra samosas from the launch of the Grenfell charity cookbook.  But what would happen  any of them were actually to do something illegal - would they be arrested or would they get away with it simply because of who they are? Here's everything you need to know...   After marrying in to the most famous family in the country, Meghan Markle and Kate Middleton inherited many fabulous perks - from dazzling tiaras to household chefs and drivers.   However there is one royal perk that by far outweighs the rest and that is Sovereign Immunity - but only The Queen has it.  This is a law which states that the sovereign cannot commit a legal wrong and is thus immune from civil suit or criminal prosecution.  Therefore The Queen is completely above the law, she can quite literally do no wrong. But according to the royal family's website, she still likes to make sure she remains on the straight and narrow: Although civil and criminal proceedings cannot be taken against the Sovereign as a person under UK law, The Queen is careful to ensure that all her activities in her personal capacity are carried out in strict accordance with the law. Unfortunately for other members of the royal household, this blanket immunity does not apply to anyone else.  So for the likes of Prince Charles , Prince William , Prince Harry , Kate Middleton and Meghan Markle, there is a price to be paid for committing a crime.   Of course, being royalty, when it comes to their punishment there are a few loopholes. According to the legal encyclopedia Halsbury's Laws of England, members of the royal household cannot be arrested in civil proceedings, arrests can't take place in the monarch's presence and they also cannot be arrested anywhere near a palace. One royal has already been given a criminal conviction.

title: mum easyjet flight told staff
story: NewsMum on easyJet flight told by staff to stop breastfeeding mid way through nursing sonKelly Edgson-Payne has flown with son Lex 16 times in the last year and has never had this problem beforeShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsBySarah Lumley12:25, 26 SEP 2018Updated12:48, 26 SEP 2018NewsKelly Edgson-Payne and her son Lex "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA furious mum-of-four has slammed easyJet after she was made to stop breastfeeding her baby during a flight and had to pry the infant off her mid-feed. Kelly Edgson-Payne was mortied and in tears when a male member of cabin crew told her she could not feed her one-year-old son Lex during take-off. The 36-year-old was flying from London Gatwick to Fuerteventura, Spain, on August 20, with her husband Ross, 40, and four children, when the unpleasant incident happened. Kelly, from Rochester, Kent, said: It's just absolutely crazy that I was told that I couldn't feed him - crazy, and really embarrassing for me.  Kelly - who says she has never had an issue breastfeeding any of her children on flights - has now hit out at easyJet for not seeming to know the law about breastfeeding. I find it really disappointing that an airline I trust, and who we fly with all the time, actually broke the law in discriminating against me as a breastfeeding mother, she said. The law in the UK says it protects breastfeeding mothers - and even easyJet's own website says mothers are welcome to breastfeed at any time during a flight. There's just no consistency in their messages. They should not be discriminating against breastfeeding.  When the sports therapist raised the issue with easyJet Customer Services, she was told she was welcome to breastfeed her baby on their flights - as long as you are discreet. She added: We fly with easyJet literally all the time, and I have always breastfed all my children over the years during take-off - because their ears pop and its uncomfortable for them. Most other cabin crew would actually encourage breastfeeding during take-off, because it distracts them and stops them from crying. I've never before been told that I can't feed Lex, or any of my other children - and we've flown with him about 16 times in the last year. So I got settled into my seat and I started to feed my son, as I would usually. Then a male member of cabin crew came over and told me I couldn't feed him during take-off, and that I'd have to stop and strap him in to his infant seat next to me. Kelly continued: It was just crazy. I said, 'Well, he's feeding'. But I just had to stop mid-feed and hand him to my husband.  I was mortied. I'm not afraid to breastfeed my baby wherever - I've stopped at a break point during a marathon before and fed him - but this left me embarrassed and in tears. I had to very quickly cover myself up - but my breasts were still leaking milk, because I had stopped mid-feed. Even my eldest daughter, who is nine, said, 'Mummy, they can't tell you not to breastfeed him'. Kelly, mum to Mia, nine, Elena, five, Jax, three, and Lex, one, said a female member of cabin crew later approached her after take-off and apologised for the incident. She said: The two of them had a bit of a hoo-ha, and she then later came up to me and said, 'I'm sorry about that, ignore him, he's wrong.' What annoys and disappoints me is that there is no consistency. On their website they state, 'We support breastfeeding mothers and you can feed your baby on board at any time'. But when I emailed their customer services about it afterwards, I was told, 'Passengers are allowed to breastfeed their babies on board the aircraft, as long as you are doing this in a discreet manner'.  The ironic thing is, since having my third and fourth children, whenever I fly I have always booked my infant a seat next to me. So I've never in the last six years sat next to a random passenger. Up until the cabin crew told me I couldn't breastfeed, I don't think any other passengers were even paying any attention to me at all. Kelly added that all easyJet offered her in the way of compensation was a &pound25 voucher to be used on another flight with them. She said: I just want them to make themselves aware of the law so no other mums have to go through this.

story: NewsPaul Gascoigne's nephew accidentally overdosed on fatal cocktail of drugs, coroner rulesJay Lennon Gascoigne, 22, was found dead at his girlfriend's home in Gateshead, Tyne and WearShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBradley Jolly18:00, 26 SEP 2018NewsJay Gascoigne, also known as Jay Kerrigan, died in April 2016 "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Paul Gascoigne's young nephew died as a result of an accidental drugs overdose, his inquest heard.  Jay Lennon Gascoigne, 22, was found dead at his girlfriend's home in Gateshead, Tyne and Wear.  A court heard he had battled mental health issues from the age of 13 and became dependant on drugs and alcohol, occasionally bought off the internet.  But today - the third day of his inquest in Hebburn, Tyne and Wear - the coroner ruled Mr Gascoigne took a fatal cocktail of drugs despite repeated warnings from health professionals in his last months.  However, Terence Carney, coroner for Gateshead and South Tyneside, ruled the death was accidental.  The court heard how Mr Gascoigne, previously known as Kerrigan, suffered from obsessive compulsive disorder  from childhood which caused him anxiety and distress, with intrusive thoughts, when he was growing up.   His distraught mum Anna Kerrigan said in a statement he seemed to fall between the crack of mental health and drug services.  Mental health services needed him to be free from drugs to be able to clearly diagnose his condition as an adult, the court heard.  And drug services required his ongoing mental health issues to be addressed in order to help him. The coroner rejected that there were systemic failures which contributed signicantly to his death in April 2016. Mr Carney said Mr Gascoigne presented with a complex medical profile, which included OCD and poly-drug use. The coroner said: I am not satisfied that he deliberately intended to self-harm, I question whether he fully understood or appreciated, despite the number of times he would be told, the real dangers that he faced. To lose a child at such a tender age, against a background of such intensive management care by the family, and particularly mum, must be heart-rending in the extreme.

story: NewsTruth behind man shouting into bored woman's ear in 'most relatable nightclub photo in history'The picture has been shared all over the world - and people are imagining what he's sayingShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicola OakleyHead of Audience12:27, 26 SEP 2018Updated14:10, 26 SEP 2018News "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA photograph of a man shouting into a woman's ear in the middle of a nightclub has gone viral after being dubbed 'the most relatable nightclub photo in history'. The image, taken in Milk in Edinburgh, shows a young woman in a red dress looking distinctly unimpressed and staring into space while a man leans, shouting, into the side of her face. It looks like a classic nightclub scene of a girl being chatted up by a stranger who has, well, no chat. But the people in the picture have revealed the truth - and it proves you shouldn't judge a book by its cover.  The hilarious snap became popular when Alex Hall, from London, posted the photo on his Facebook page.   Alex wrote: with the caption: Congratulations to Milk in Edinburgh on taking what I suspect may be the most relatable nightclub photo in the history of the art. His post has received more than 12,000 shares and 20,000 'Reactions' and people have been giving the image their own captions, imagining what the young man is saying. One commented: 'No, seriously... You just don't understand how important Pat Nevin was to Tranmere Rovers' success in the 90s. Honestly, he was that good, it was worth getting into the Cow Shed in time to see him warm up... Oh man! The photo has been shared all over the world, with some editing it into existing memes.   Thankfully, the man and woman in the picture have revealed themselves so we don't have to keep guessing what he was talking about. Patrick Ritchie and pal Lucia Gorman called Capital Radio to unmask themselves as the duo - but confessed they have no idea what he was saying at the time to bore her to tears.  Patrick said: She's one of my pals from school so she's probably fed up. She looks like the most bored woman in the world. Lucia agreed, saying: I don't remember [what he was saying]. Patrick always talks rubbish so it could have been anything.

title: bible story exodus could true
story: NewsBible story of Exodus 'could be true' as archaeologists discover 'ancient' ruins near River JordanExperts are analysing whether ruins are proof of a nomadic Israelite people crossing into the ancient land from outsideShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMichael Havis14:11, 26 SEP 2018NewsArchaeologists are analysing whether the ruins, named Khirbet el Mastarah, are consistent with a newly-arrived nomadic people "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailArchaeologists have discovered 'ancient' ruins near the River Jordan in what could be the first ever evidence of the Biblical story of Exodus, it is claimed. In the Bible, Moses is said to have liberated the Israelites from slavery in Egypt and led them through the wilderness of Sinai, before they crossed the River Jordan into the promised land of Canaan. However, no historical basis for the account exists and archaeologists generally agree that the Israelites were, in fact, native to Canaan - an ancient region covering modern day Israel. But now, experts are analysing whether ruins near the river are proof of a nomadic Israelite people crossing into the ancient land from outside. Some claim it could be the first ever evidence of the Biblical account.  We have not proved that these camps are from the period of of the early Israelites, but it is possible, said David Ben-Shlomo, an archaeologist with Ariel University. If they are, this might fit the biblical story of the Israelites coming from east of the Jordan River, then crossing the Jordan and entering into the hill country of Israel later. Archaeologists are analysing whether the ruins, named Khirbet el Mastarah, are consistent with a newly-arrived nomadic people. Pottery shards from the site have been dated to the early Iron Age, around the time traditionally associated with the Israelite arrival. Meanwhile, the ruins themselves, a number of low walls, are believed to be rudimentary stone fencing for animals - consistent with known nomadic practices.  According to Dr Ben-Shlomo and his American dig partner, Ralph Hawkins of Averett University, this could explain why pottery shards at the site were found outside - not inside - the stone walls. The floors of the structures were virtually empty of finds, and thus, we could not date them by conventional archaeological methods, they said. In Bedouin settlements, people live in tents made of perishables which are relocated every season, thus artacts would not be associated with stone architecture. So the structures might have housed animals, rather than people, who lived in tents around them. The site, five miles north of Jericho, is also said to make more sense as a nomadic settlement than a permanent one. Temperatures there can easily reach a searing 45C, while annual rainfall is as little as 1cm.  The landscape is arid most of the time and even in modern times most of the population here are Bedouins, said Dr Ben-Shlomo. Furthermore, the site is isolated and is shielded from view by the surrounding hills - perhaps implying a new population in fear of a hostile reception. Now, the archaeologists are working to confirm whether site is as old as they suspect. Dr Ben-Shlomo said: Sites like Khirbet el Mastarah and other similar ones in the Jordan Valley seem - at least from survey material - to appear suddenly during the Iron Age. Since this area is not densely populated in many periods, this might indicate a new phenomenon like nomads suddenly creating settlements, or a new population.  Soil samples from Khirbet el Mastarah have now been sent for analysis. Samples from beneath the walls will be tested for a build-up of electrons, which get trapped over the years and are only released by light radiation. They could reveal the age of the structure, it is claimed. Meanwhile, samples from between the walls will be tested for elevated levels of phosphorus, which would be consistent with animal dung accruing in them. Results are expected in a few months. The archaeologists are also planning to excavate nearby Uja el-Foqa to determine whether it might be linked to Israelite settlement of the region. However the work is not without its challenges - archaeologists must look for cultural clues that the site was indeed Israelite. It is dficult since many aspects of the material culture of dferent groups  may be too similar or not indicative enough, said Dr Ben-Shlomo.

title: woman 25 huge 5ft iphone
story: NewsWoman, 25, has huge 5ft iPhone headstone over burial plot with picture of her as 'screensaver'One cemetery visitor thought he was "having hallucinations" when he saw the gravestone for Rita ShameevaShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByWill Stewart08:12, 26 SEP 2018Updated08:14, 26 SEP 2018NewsRita's iPhone headstone "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA 25-year-old woman has been buried underneath a massive iPhone headstone - leaving mourners stunned. The unusual 5ft tombstone was put up over Rita Shameeva's burial plot in a Russian cemetery earlier this year. The gravestone features a picture of Rita leaning against railings and surrounded by trees in a park. It even has the Apple logo on the back. It was erected by her grieving father Rais Shameev long after his daughter's death in January 2016 from an unknown cause, say reports. He has not commented on the unusual memorial.  It is made from basalt in the shape of a black iPhone. And the 5ft high monument towers above other gravestones in this part of Ufa cemetery. Mourner Nikolay Yevdokimov told newspaper ProUral: “I thought I was having hallucinations. “How could an American smartphone suddenly appear at our cemetery? “And such a huge one.  “I came closer and was surprised. “I've seen many gravestones, but to make one in the form of iPhone - this is the first time, to be honest. “It was made for a young woman from black basalt most likely. Very unusual.” Little is known of Rita except that she was a keen traveller and had friends in Germany. Local headstone maker Ilgam Galliulin denied he was responsible for its design.

title: dundee boss neil mccann has three games to save his job
story: Patience is wearing thin with the Dundee hierarchy and manager Neil McCann has just three matches to save his job.The Tele understands the Dark Blues boss has until the next international break to turn his side’s fortunes around.However, a heavy loss to Hibs today followed by defeat to Hamilton next week could accelerate that process.The Tele also believes there is appetite for change at Dens and owner Tim Keyes and managing director John Nelms have been urged to sound out potential successors to McCann.However, the key decision-makers at the club are prepared to give the current gaffer more time to get the results that could kickstart the Dark Blues’ season.That patience will only last so long, though.Next week’s trip to Hamilton is followed by a home game against Steve Clarke’s Kilmarnock before the Premiership takes another break with international football taking over.By then, results are a must  Neil is continue in his role as manager.Meanwhile, the Dens gaffer will be hoping for a midfield boost today against Hibs.Glen Kamara has missed almost the entire season, starting just the opening Betfred Cup group stage win over Stirling Albion and the 1-0 defeat at St Johnstone three weeks ago.The Finnish international injured his ankle after that victory in Stirling and has struggled on with it since.He suffered a recurrence a fortnight ago as he prepared to travel to join up with his national side and then missed last week’s trip to Ibrox.He has, though, ed to training this week and is hoping to be fit enough to play a part against the Hibees at Dens today.

title: dundee united defender freddy frans not worried about falkirks artificial pitch
story: After two full seasons in the Championship it is clear being big fish in a small pond has been of no benefit to Dundee United.And that is something Freddy Frans is well aware of with the defender insisting they have to fight to win points in a league where the pressure is always on.Since their relegation from the Premiership in 2016, United have twice fell in the campaign-closing promotion play-offs and currently lie fth in the table after a sticky start.They travel through to Falkirk today to face a Bairns side managed by ex-Terrors boss Ray McKinnon, something which could add an extra element of pressure for Csaba Laszlo’s team.However, 29-year-old Frans insists that is something they must learn to cope with while picking up the points.“That’s one of the reasons why I wanted to play for Dundee United,” he said.“I wanted the pressure. I am not a player made for playing without any pressure because then I wouldn’t be playing well.“I need pressure to thrive and it’s a big club – it should be in the Premiership.“It’s about how we deal with the pressure and Dundee United is probably the team with the most pressure on it in this league.“You feel like the fans definitely want to get out of the Championship. I want to get out of the Championship as well.“I’m not coming here to play my two seasons on my contract in the Championship.“It’s going to be a tough game and, in this league, every game is tough. It’s not because they are bottom of the league that we should underestimate them.“They have a new coach and they showed last week they played very good in the first half and the thing is they have nothing to lose, we have everything to lose.“You see in this league there is not one game you can predict. Everybody can beat each other.”After disappointing draws against Alloa and Morton in recent weeks, Frans knows there can be no more excuses.He has captained the side in the absence of the likes of Fraser Fyvie and Stewart Murdoch and feels they are now more equipped, with their ‘leaders’ coming back to the squad, to go on a winning run.“If you look at the way we played last weekend, we had 11 players starting who weren’t here last year but still we produce some good stuff,” he added.“We need to be more efficient. We missed a few chances but also we concede every game.“I do think we defend well but somehow we concede a penalty and the week before it was a free-kick against Alloa.“It is not because of bad defending, just small things, and we need to get better at them.“I think you see every week we are improving but, OK, there comes a time you need to put it in results and start to go on a run.“You see Fraser Fyvie coming back, Billy King, Sam Stanton is still injured, Murdoch is out.“These are players who would walk into a lot of Championship teams and be the leaders.“There are positive things to look forward to.”United will go toe-to-toe with pointless bottom side Falkirk today on an articial surface.However, Frans says they will not be using that or the ongoing stormy weather as excuses for another disappointing display.“I don’t like to talk about the pitch because I don’t want to have any excuses. Whatever pitch it is we should play well.“We went to Queen of the South and I think the first half we produced one of the best performances since I’ve been here.“You come up against dferent circumstances and maybe it’s going to be 100mph wind.“Every week it’s something so  you think too much about circumstances you are not focused.”

title: george cran dundee can get out of this mess theyve done it before
story: On the whole, no points by this stage of the season brings about relegation. Dundee will be hoping they can buck the trend – and they do have some form for it.Try to recall horric starts in the top flight for clubs – St Mirren in 2014, Livingston in 2005, Hamilton 1989, Dumbarton 1984 and Morton 1987 – and they all end in the same horror show of the drop.In 2014, the Buddies had to wait till their sixth game before picking up points, ending in bottom spot with 30 points. Post-administration Livingston took a massive 15 games to get a victory in 2005 with just one point from their first seven.You get the idea.For the Dark Blues, though, there is a small chink of sunshine, a ray of hope for the most optimistic fans to cling on to despite having no points from the first six games.The ‘12th team’ season was a poor one, of course, with plenty of reasons behind a dreadful start.A side built to get promotion from the First Division was suddenly parachuted into the top flight as Rangers were booted out.And Barry Smith’s side struggled badly. However, by this point, even they had four points from their first six games.Overall, though, nine losses in 11 games was a recipe for disaster and ended with relegation in bottom spot with 30 points.Head back to 1993 and Simon Stainrod’s final few games in charge tell a similar story to Dundee’s current predicament.No wins to their name, two draws however, led to Stainrod being moved from a manager role to director of football with his No 2 Jim Duffy taking over.They eventually beat Hearts on October 2, 1993, with goals from Garry Paterson and Dragutin Ristic.In the first of his three spells as gaffer at Dens, Duffy as player-manager couldn’t keep the Dark Blues from finishing in bottom spot – a side that eventually included a very young Neil McCann.However, head back to the early 80s and a spell where Dundee were perennially bad starters to seasons.Starting in 1980/81, Donald Mackay’s Dark Blues certainly weren’t early risers.In the First Division, that season saw no wins in the opening seven matches with two 0-0 draws at least putting something on the board.Remarkably, they didn’t manage to score a single goal in the league until the fth game.Brian Scrimgeour broke that duck in a 2-1 defeat at Hibs before they finally managed a victory at the eighth time of asking.That saw Eric Sinclair grab two along with goals from John Fletcher and Peter Mackie in a 4-0 success over Falkirk.Fast forward to the end of the campaign and that sluggish start didn’t hurt too much as Mackay’s men won promotion to the top flight, finishing second to Hibs, scoring 64 goals on the way.Two campaigns later and it was a similar story to today.The Dark Blues were yet to pick up a victory in the Premier Division by October 1 in 1983/84.At that time, there had only been five league games by that point with a League Cup group stage taking up the early fixtures.Only a 0-0 draw with St Mirren gave them anything before two own goals from Motherwell got them up and running.Eventually, Mackay’s reign came to an end in December of that year.In his place came Archie Knox to keep them in the ision, finishing four points ahead of St Johnstone.Signings like John Brown and Robert Connor saw Knox transform the Dark Blues into a solid mid-table outfit before Jocky Scott took over for the first time in 1986 and continued that.Dundee have history of getting themselves out of bad starts – whether they stick like they did with Mackay or twist with someone like Knox, they have previous.

title: inniss calls on dundee team mates to show character after seventh straight defeat
story: Ryan Inniss has told his Dundee team-mates to look within themselves and find the fight that will rescue boss Neil McCann from the sack.The Dens Park boss is clinging on to his job after a seventh straight defeat against Hibernian on Saturday.The 3-0 loss to Neil Lennon&#8217s men means the Dark Blues have yet to take a point from their six Ladbrokes Premiership fixtures so far this season.Now next week&#8217s trip to Hamilton is looking like a make-or-break showdown for McCann&#8217s reign &#8211 so long as Dee chiefs do not decide to act before then.With so much hanging on that clash, Crystal Palace loanee Inniss knows his side cannot lie down as meekly as they did against Hibs.But the centre-back says it is down to his new colleagues to find the desire that will halt their slide &#8211 not their manager.He said: &#8220We will go again but we have got to take it personally, I mean really, really personally.&#8220We&#8217re talking about character here &#8211 not ability.&#8220For me, you find your level with ability eventually. But character &#8211 that can drop you out the game quicker than anything.&#8220The things the manager is teaching us from the sidelines, we can do them.&#8220But you can&#8217t teach us character. It&#8217s too late in le. We&#8217ve got to find that ourselves. Whether it&#8217s a time in our lives when we were really down and came back from it, then we have got to replicate that.&#8220It&#8217s that deep, it really is.&#8220Fans will accept  a player isn&#8217t the best player but gives 100 per cent &#8211 but they must be coming away here having paid their hard-earned money thinking, &#8216They gave up again&#8217. It&#8217s not good enough.&#8221Former Dundee winger Martin Boyle ed to Tayside to deliver the latest blow to McCann&#8217s job prospects, laying on Florian Kamberi&#8217s 51st-minute opener before rling home a quick-fire second soon after.But the lightning-quick attacker, speaking after a victory that was wrapped up in stoppage time by Thomas Agyepong, admits he has sympathy for his old side.&#8220We knew it would be a real six-pointer and that Dundee would be up for it,&#8221 he said.&#8220We had to ride the wave the first 10 minutes but after that we were in control.&#8220I feel for the guys at Dundee, 100 per cent. It&#8217s not a nice situation they are in but we had a job to do and hopefully both of us can start picking up wins now.&#8221

title: Future of riverside hotel plan is unclear
story: &nbspIT is unclear  ambitious plans for a new hotel on the site of a former Inverness swimming pool have been permanently sunk by councillors&rsquo rejection of the project.The south Highland planning committee narrowly refused to grant planning permission for a 168-bedroom hotel, restaurant, bar and leisure complex at Glebe Street in Inverness because of the design.Keppie Design' visualisation was iously branded "bogging, hideous" and reminiscent of bleak architecture from the "Stalinist" era. The developer, Dutch property firm Vastint Hospitality, could not be contacted.A y Inverness debate ended on Tuesday with an 8-7 vote to refuse the application despite Ness-side SNP councillor Ron MacWilliam' insistence that the vision was that of "a grand building, that you&rsquod expect to see in a serious city centre".Inverness Central ward party colleague Richard Laird, however, successfully argued that it "failed to make a positive contribution to the city' architecture," and therefore contravened the local plan.He described the design as "absolutely bogging" and "exactly the same as some of those we&rsquore so desperate to tear down in the middle of Inverness".He and several committee colleagues were also concerned about the potential impact of future traffic movement in Waterloo Place and Glebe Street as a result of the proposed development.There was general support for a hotel to be built at the location but Cllr Laird said the drawing board proposition "looks exactly the same as some of those we&rsquore so desperate to teardown in the middle of Inverness" &ndash a reference to the council' recent approval for bulldozing and replacing the &lsquo60s-built Bridge Street "blots on the landscape".Committee colleague Bill Lobban considered the hotel design "hideous".He said: "It' the most visible site in the whole of Inverness. It' a very important site but it deserves something better than this. This Lego-style block might have been contemporary in 1960s East Germany looking from the wrong side of the Berlin Wall."Echoing that, Councillor Andrew Baxter said he had seen similar "Stalinist" architecture in Moldova.Peter Andrews, managing director of Vastint Hospitality, said: &ldquoWe&rsquore disappointed. We want to wait to see the council' written reasons for refusal.&ldquoWhen we&rsquove had a chance to review it with Keppies and probably a planning consultant then we&rsquoll decide what we&rsquore going to do.A spokesman for Keppie Design said: "We&rsquore naturally disappointed by the narrow decision to refuse planning permission for the scheme as it stands, despite officers recommending approval."The design is an honest, contemporary response to a high-profile site, using a selection of high-quality materials and massing relevant to the hotel use."The detail of the aesthetic and the proportions of the design have been signicantly remodelled following several post-submission meetings with the planning authority."Former Highland planning chairman Thomas Prag, who opposed a previous development proposal for the site while a serving councillor, said he was "relieved" his successors had done the same."I&rsquom disappointed with the architects, who are well known and do some great stuff," he said."I think they were too constrained by their client' building methods. It was a wrong design for the location and would have resembled the old HIE building in Bridge Street."Meanwhile, a proposed 111-home development, 300 yards southeast of the Simpsons garden centre in Inverness, edged a step closer with the submission of planning advice notes from the applicants DMPM Services.Thursday 27 Sep 2018 4:36 AM&nbsp&nbsp
